[DOC 1] New Delhi: Often when we break up with someone we are left wondering if we did the right thing or made a huge mistake. Since we all know love is not easy to find, we fixate on this and find ourselves in a limbo of considering the options which are, go back or move on.

While some relationships can be rekindled with time and space, others were never meant to stand the test of time. Take a look at signs that will show you whether it can work, or if it's time to move on.
Signs It Can Work

Communication improvements: Has there been a change in how you communicate your feelings to each other? Often, the cause of why people break up is not being able to truly understand one another and be patient towards how their partner is feeling, to fix the relationship. Do you think that after some time apart you can talk to them more openly and there's a commitment towards doing this more effectively?Reflection: Have you both taken the time to understand where the relationship went wrong and what would be different this time? Taking the time to reflect is very crucial. While you may miss someone, you must know exactly what you want done differently or can do differently this time around. You also have to take into consideration if the two of you have grown individually during your time apart. This will allow the two of you to start fresh and deepen your connection if the two of you have evolved positively.Have the reasons you broke up been resolved? Going back to the same issues will never work. You will just end up where you left off. Knowing exactly what they are and being able to make the required changes so they don't happen again, is the attitude the two of you need, to make this work. It’s a joint effort and having this clarity is the most important thing.Love: Yes, it's a cliche, but we can't ignore it because, as I mentioned, it's the most challenging thing to find. If both of you genuinely love each other and share equal commitment, adopting the attitude of "whatever comes our way, we'll work through it" is feasible. However, don't cling to this idea if it isn't working. True love has the power to mend issues and bring harmony. If it lacks harmony, then perhaps this isn't the right love for you.

Signs It Won't Work

Your values and goals don't align: If you and your partner do not share the same view of the future, it will always be an issue because, over time, this will lead to resentment. The destination has to be the same for both of you. If both of you want different things, then your paths can never merge. Also, your core morals, knowing right from wrong, need to align. You need to have a shared view of an inner compass that you both live by. Without this, there will always be conflict.

Lack of effort: As the saying goes, it takes two hands to clap. If one person is putting in all the effort to get the relationship on track again, yet the other isn't, then you need to reevaluate this. Getting a relationship to work once it has a crack is hard work and a joint effort. If one of you is showing disinterest or not investing time, then this implies that the effort is completely one-sided.

Repeated Issues: If the same issues keep popping up, then this will never work. For relationships to work, past baggage has to be left in the past. If even after trying to resolve them they still keep popping up, then that means they are still very much in the present. And, after everything, if it's still there, then you have to consider that perhaps it'll never be resolved.

Lack of emotional or physical intimacy: If there is a disconnect between these two things and you don't know why, it's because there is a possibly much deeper underlying issue. Without these two things, a relationship can never flourish, and it can never grow. It will also feel like something is missing.

Figuring out whether to go back to a relationship or move on can leave you in a place of limbo. However, getting your answers is the best thing you can do for yourself. Don’t be afraid to figure it out and take the call. Whatever happens, you are going to end up exactly where you need to be. A wise person once said to me, "Treat your love life like a book. For you to know how the story ends, you need to be brave enough to turn the page."
reference_summary: Navigating post-breakup uncertainty can be daunting. Signs it might work include improved communication, resolved past issues, shared reflection, and genuine love. Signs it might not work include misaligned values, lack of joint effort, recurring issues, and a gap in intimacy. Ultimately, clarity empowers you to turn the page, leading you to where you're meant to be.

input_text: [DOC 1] Mumbai: The automobile industry has been hit by demonetisation and the uncertainty created by the sudden ban on vehicles with engines adhering to Bharat Stage-III (BS-III) emission norms, fresh data shows. Their twin impact on the sales of passenger vehicles, commercial vehicles and two wheelers has seen total turnover of automobile and engine manufacturers in India increase by just 7.4% to ₹ 4.76 trillion in financial year 2017, while total profit of the automobile companies increased by 11.8% to ₹ 35,013.17 crore, according to the latest date compiled by the Society of Automobile manufacturers (Siam) and Centre for Monitoring India Economy Pvt. Ltd (CMEI).
reference_summary: The Indian automotive industry faced challenges due to demonetization and the abrupt ban on vehicles adhering to Bharat Stage-III (BS-III) emission norms. Despite these hurdles, data from the Society of Automobile Manufacturers (SIAM) and Centre for Monitoring India Economy Pvt. Ltd (CMEI) showed a modest 7.4% increase in total turnover to ₹4.76 trillion in the fiscal year 2017. However, the sector experienced a more significant growth in total profits, with automobile companies recording an 11.8% increase to ₹35,013.17 crore during the same period.

[DOC 1] Individuals lacking a solid grasp of personal finance can turn to the widely acclaimed publication “The Simple Path to Wealth: Your Guide to Financial Independence and a Fulfilling, Unrestricted Life" authored by JL Collins. Collins, an author and speaker in the realm of personal finance, imparts his wisdom on investing, money management, and life. In addition to maintaining a blog, he has authored "The Simple Path to Wealth," a book aimed at guiding contemporary investors in effectively managing their personal finances.The book promotes a clear-cut strategy for investment, emphasizing the use of low-cost index funds and the power of long-term compounding. It underscores the importance of maintaining a lifestyle below one’s financial means, automating investment processes, and steering clear of unnecessary fees.Moreover, this book encapsulates a more encompassing philosophy of financial planning. It advocates for streamlining your financial approach, concentrating on essential principles, and steering clear of intricate or high-risk strategies. The objective is to steadily and consistently accumulate wealth over time, eschewing the pursuit of quick-rich schemes. Several fundamental principles frequently linked to this book, essentially serving as a guide to understanding how to navigate personal finance decisions, encompass:

Living within your financial limits
The foundation for wealth-building lies in living beneath your means. It involves a deliberate decision to expend less than what you earn, channelling the excess towards savings and investments. While it may appear straightforward, this is a potent principle with the potential to significantly influence your financial future.

The concept of spending less than you earn entails monitoring your expenditures, developing a budget, and pinpointing areas where you can economize. It’s important to note that it’s not about deprivation; instead, it’s about making intelligent choices that align with your long-term objectives.

Putting money into low-cost index funds
Putting your money into low-cost index funds provides an excellent means to construct a diversified portfolio and attain robust long-term returns. To begin with, index funds offer extensive market exposure by tracking specific market indices such as the S&P 500 or a total stock market index. This implies immediate ownership of a diverse basket containing hundreds or even thousands of stocks, effectively spreading risk across various companies, sectors, and industries.

Furthermore, the diversification resulting from investments in index funds helps mitigate market fluctuations. With no single company or sector exerting a significant impact on your investment portfolio, this approach provides stability in contrast to concentrated holdings.

Additionally, index funds passively follow indexes, minimizing management expenses. With expense ratios much lower than those of actively managed funds, they incur significantly fewer charges, allowing you to retain a greater portion of your investment returns. Reduced fees enable your returns to compound over time, exerting a significant influence on your long-term wealth. Even a slight disparity in fees can accumulate into a substantial sum in the future.

Adopting a long-term perspective 
Adopting a long-term perspective forms the foundation of successful index fund investing. Consider an 8% annual return on investments over the next 10 years. While that results in a substantial gain, the real power of compounding becomes evident over 30 years, when your money more than quadruples. The compounding effect, where your returns earn returns, creates a snowball effect, accelerating the creation of wealth.

The greater the duration of your investment, the more compounding has the opportunity to work its magic. Early contributions and consistent investments, even in modest amounts, can have a substantial impact on your future nest egg. Over time, short-term market fluctuations become less relevant. While individual years may experience gains or losses, adopting a long-term perspective helps smooth out these fluctuations, enabling compounding to fulfill its potential.

Shifting your focus to decades rather than days reduces anxiety related to market fluctuations. By placing trust in the long-term trend, you steer clear of the temptation to engage in panic selling or make impulsive decisions.

Set your investments on auto mode
Implementing financial automation is akin to putting your wealth-building on cruise control, seamlessly steering you toward a more prosperous future. It serves as a clandestine tool for numerous accomplished investors. Automating your finances involves regularly transferring predetermined amounts from your checking account to your specified goals, day in and day out. Once set, you can leave it to operate in the background, and yet, your wealth continues to flourish.

Firstly, it alleviates the challenge of saving when confronted with enticing expenses. Automation eliminates the temptation, guaranteeing that your financial priorities are addressed before you even consider spending. It’s a case of “out of sight, out of mind", all the while steadily enhancing your financial security.

The appeal of automation resides in its unwavering consistency. Consistent deposits harness the power of compounding, where your returns generate additional returns over time. It’s akin to a snowball effect, progressively expanding your wealth exponentially.

Don’t incur debt
Steering clear of debt, or at the very least reducing it, is a fundamental aspect of a sound financial life. Debt binds you with ongoing interest payments, depleting your income and constraining your available resources. By minimizing debt, you liberate these resources for essential needs, savings, or investments.

Reduced debt means having more liquid funds for daily expenditures, emergencies, or unforeseen opportunities. This provides financial flexibility, eliminating the stress of managing numerous debt payments. Maintaining low levels of debt contributes to a positive credit score, paving the way for improved loan terms, lower interest rates, and even favourable insurance premiums. A robust credit score becomes a valuable asset for upcoming financial endeavours.

Investing principles don’t have to be tedious and intricate. While it’s true that elaborate money-making strategies can come with a high cost, and though some have proven beneficial in the long run, JL Collins offers a perspective on personal finance that is accessible and straightforward. His skill in making dull financial concepts amusing and engaging highlights how savings and investments can be straightforward for those ready to take control of their finances.
reference_summary: "The Simple Path to Wealth" by JL Collins is a widely acclaimed guide to personal finance, offering straightforward and accessible advice on investing, money management, and life. The book advocates for a clear-cut investment strategy, emphasizing low-cost index funds and the power of long-term compounding. Key principles include living within one's financial limits, spending less than earning, and making intelligent choices aligned with long-term objectives. The importance of putting money into low-cost index funds is highlighted for constructing a diversified portfolio with robust long-term returns. Adopting a long-term perspective is emphasized, showcasing the power of compounding over time. Automation of finances, setting investments on autopilot, is recommended to ensure consistency and harness the benefits of compounding. Avoiding debt or minimizing it is considered fundamental for financial well-being, providing flexibility and positively impacting credit scores. Overall, the book simplifies investing principles, making them accessible for those looking to take control of their finances.

fatigue and increases driving comfort. The design incorporates a pendulum pneumatic engine and special tyres.
Anil Sharma, also from Bangalore, has mooted solar-powered computers. In fact, solar energy is clearly on top of the
mind, with several ideas suggesting solar panels for everything from lighting commercial buildings to storing solar
energy in car batteries.Another interesting model comes from Air Commodore HSR Arora.He who suggests that each
house can generate electricity by using 'levitation technology'.

He says the captured carbon dioxide "can be converted to green fuel to run the vehicle". Sahoo has filed a patent for his

design.
In a quirky, if workable, idea from Mumbai, Suresh Kumar suggests digging small holes of 10 mm diameter at regular
intervals on concrete surfaces such as pavements, in order to allow rainwater to percolate into the ground.

reference_summary: The Times of India-Garnier Take Care Take Charge (TCTC) campaign has garnered significant public engagement across India, with over 10,000 participants signing up on Facebook and more than 2,000 ideas and pledges received so far. The campaign, originally scheduled to end on July 1, 2011, has extended its submission deadline to July 3 due to overwhelming response. Participants from cities like Mumbai, Chennai, Bangalore, Kolkata, and Delhi are proposing innovative environmental solutions, such as solar-powered technologies, carbon dioxide capture boxes for cars, and rainwater percolation methods. Finalists will be selected city-wise on July 8, with national winners announced on July 18, leading up to Take Care Take Charge Day on July 24.

[DOC 1] Himachal Pradesh news: Tourist destinations in Himachal Pradesh like Kasol and Manali are witnessing massive traffic congestion as tourists flock the hill stations causing slow vehicular movement as Christmas Eve nears.

Further Atal Tunnel in Rohtang Pass received fresh snowfall on Saturday.
The Atal Tunnel, an engineering marvel in the Himalayas, is a highway tunnel constructed under the Rohtang Pass in the eastern Pir Panjal range. Located on the Leh-Manali Highway in Himachal Pradesh, India, it holds the distinction of being the longest single-tube highway tunnel situated above 10,000 feet, as per the Border Roads Organisation's official website.

On Thursday, the police in Shimla district said they were anticipating a huge rush of visitors ahead of Christmas and the year-end festivities.
Police said they were expecting over one lakh tourist vehicles to roll into the hill town in the last week of December, on the eve of Christmas and New Year.
The Mayor of Shimla City has planned the first-ever winter carnival to draw tourists to the state for the year-end festivities and frolicking while also promoting the traditions and culture of Himachal Pradesh.

Tourists have already started arriving in the hilly state in large numbers in anticipation of snowfall in the exotic locales as the year draws to a close.
Speaking to ANI, Sanjeev Kumar Gandhi, Superintendent of Police (SP) of Shimla, said, "The police are expecting over one lakh tourist vehicles to roll into the hill town in the last week of this year."

[DOC 1] LUCKNOW: After former director-general of police Prakash Singh, it is now the turn of the UP Provincial Services Association (UPPSA) to test the government's commitment, if any, to uphold the citizen's right to information as provided under the Right to Information Act, 2005.
The association has fired five queries seeking details regarding promotion of officers from other state services to IAS cadre and postings of PCS officers.

If the state government answers honestly, the questions would expose alleged anomalies in the out-of-turn promotions of 'favourite' officers.
Submitted through proper channel, Hardev Singh, president UPPSA, has asked Mohan Singh Chauhan, principal secretary and state public information officer, appointment department, to reply and furnish details as per Right to Information Act.


In the first question, Singh has asked the government why only one PCS officer ��� RK Singh��� was promoted to IAS cadre in 2001 and the remaining seven posts earmarked to be filled through PCS officers were left vacant.
Further, was there any proposal under government's consideration to promote officers from other state services to the seven posts?

The second question hits state government's reported move to promote seven 'favourite' officers from other state services.

Giving reference of rules that officers having outstanding merit and ability from other state services can be promoted to IAS cadre under special circumstances, that too after serving eight continuous years on a post equivalent to deputy collector, Singh has asked the government to specify its criterion to judge "outstanding merit" and what are the "posts in other state services declared equivalent to deputy collector.
He has asked for all notifications and orders issued in this regard.
The third question is even more direct. It has asked government to provide copies of directions issued by two former chief ministers in which they had ordered that "other services quota" in IAS cadre would be filled by promoting only PCS officers.


The decision was taken, keeping in view the stagnation in PCS cadre. Through the fourth question, it has asked for details of an order by a former chief minister who had directed that other state services officers considered for promotion into IAS cadre should not be junior to those PCS officers who could not get an opportunity of promotion.


The last question gives reference of government orders dated October 12, 2001, and January 13, 2003, which have categorised posts in the administration on the basis of their importance, with instructions that PCS officers will be deputed on these posts on the basis of seniority.

Singh has asked the information officer whether or not these orders are being followed and if not then the list of officers posted in violation of these orders should be provided.
reference_summary: The UP Provincial Services Association (UPPSA) has submitted five queries under the Right to Information Act, 2005, regarding the promotion of officers from other state services to the IAS cadre and the postings of PCS officers. These queries aim to uncover alleged anomalies in the promotion process and bring transparency to government actions. The questions address issues such as the criteria for promotion, vacancies in the IAS cadre, and adherence to government orders regarding postings. The association seeks details on promotions, notifications, orders, and directions issued by former chief ministers related to the promotion process.

[DOC 1] State-run Bharat Sanchar Nigam (BSNL) borrowed Rs 1,320.47 crore from the market to meet capital expenditure during 2011-12, Minister of State for Communications and IT Milind Deora has said.
"BSNL has fully met its operational expenses through internal accruals during financial year 2011-12. However, for capex authorisations, market borrowings were partially resorted to, which stood at Rs 1,320.47 crore as on March 31, 2012," Deora said in a written reply to the Lok Sabha.BSNL's losses have more than tripled to Rs 5,997 crore in 2010-11. The company had registered a loss of Rs 1,823 crore in 2009-10.BSNL had reported the highest net profit of over Rs 10,000 crore in 2005-06 but since then its profits have been falling and it reported first net loss in 2009-10.
The main reasons attributed to financial crisis in BSNL are large legacy of workforce whose salary and wages are around 50% of the revenue.
"The expenditure on this account has increased due to implementation of wage revisions," Deora said.
Other reasons include operating economically unviable rural operations as social obligation, maintenance of legacy telegraph system, payment of 3G and broadband wireless access (BWA) unfront spectrum cost to the government and maintenance of legacy wireline systems which is quite expensive.
reference_summary: State-run telecom company Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) borrowed Rs 1,320.47 crore from the market in the 2011-12 financial year to meet capital expenditure, as disclosed by Minister of State for Communications and IT Milind Deora. Despite fully covering operational expenses through internal accruals, BSNL reported losses exceeding Rs 5,997 crore in 2010-11. Factors contributing to the financial crisis include a large workforce with salary expenses consuming 50% of revenue, economically unviable rural operations, maintenance costs for legacy systems, and payments for 3G and broadband wireless access spectrum.

[DOC 1] New classical music circles in suburbs
MUMBAI: It has become routine forhomemaker Prabha Shankarto drop in at the neighbourhood hall inPowaiwith her child in tow for a bit ofclassical music. âI donât need to plan going for a concert,â says Shankar, who discovered the music circle after she moved to Powai.Attending a well-organised concert is no longer a tedious trek to the NCPA or the Dadar Matunga Cultural Centre for many like her in the suburbs.Smaller cultural groups, set up by residents starved for quality entertainment, in most city suburbs offer a minimum of four classical music concerts a year. âThere are about 25 circles that have come up in the last 20 years. Most were started by those who wanted to recreate the musical atmosphere in which they grew up in Bombay,â says Keshav Paranjape of Swar Mauli, an older circle. Paranjape is the convener of Music Organisation of Mumbai Suburbs, an association that was formed to connect old-timers with newer entrants from Kandivali, Virar and beyond.Circles come up when neighbourhoods are far away from the city centre. âTo hear a good concert we had to go all the way to NCPA or Shanmukhananda Hall. So a few of us started Powai Fine Arts three years ago,â says Ramesh Ramakrishnan, trustee.Music lovers have come together in the city in the past too. The Suburban Music Circle and Kalyan Gayan Samaj were in existence by 1930s. âIn the post-independence India, many such circles came up in Pune and Calcutta too,â says musician Satish Vyas. In Mumbai, the localities populated by Marathis, Bengalis and south Indians prominently patronised such circles, whether it is Dadar Matunga Cultural Centre (DMCC) or Vile Parle Music Circle. The scale of operations was modest to say the least. âDMCC used to rent out a room in the Chhabildas High school,â says Vyas. All the big names in Hindustani music, including Vyasâs father, the late C R Vyas and Bhimsen Joshi came there to entertain the knowledgeable audience. "The atmosphere was electric," says Vyas.Many newer circles start as informal groups. âWe were seven families in Virar who did house concerts during pujas,â says Bhupen Jagtap. In 2006, they formed Saptak and have four to five concerts a year.To students like Dhananjay Mhaskar, the circles provide a ready platform. âI was spotted by people connected to Yashwantaro Chavan Pratishthan at Swarankit circle in Nallasopara. They asked me to perform at the centre in the city. All this happened in the last two years,â says the 27-year-old.The profile of the audience has evolved, according to Kamlakar Nene of Swarankit. âAlong with older people, many youngsters and music students also come,â he says. Money problems plague circles as membership fee have not kept pace with the cost of organising concerts. Also, TV and internet keep away many young fans, says Arun Apte of Swara Vilas Foundation in Andheri.But for artists like Mhaskar, live shows offer the hope of bringing new fans. âTwo families, whose first classical concert was my show at Virar, went and bought Chaurasiaâs and Zakir Hussainâs CDs to listen to more music,â he says.

[DOC 1] A near-accident between a bike being driven by a student from Liberia and a car with a local resident at the wheel escalated into the car driver allegedly attacking the student with a stick and a few people of the neighbouring village later accusing the foreigner of writing swear words on the car, police said.

The incident took place on the outskirts of Rajkot on Saturday. Although no FIR has been filed in the matter, police said they are looking for the man who allegedly wrote the abusive words.

They further termed the accusation against the foreigner an attempt “to frame the students and raise an issue against them”. According to police, Jefferson, who has been identified by only one name, was on his way back from the market along with his two sisters when his bike almost ran into the car being driven by one Ravi in Gauridad village. Ravi got out of his car and engaged in a spat with the student of Marwadi University before hitting him with a stick on the chest, according to a statement from Kuvadva road police station on Sunday. Ravi then fled from the spot, leaving his car behind.

Meanwhile, on getting to know about the incident, a few students from Jefferson’s university arrived at the spot.

Around this time, 25 residents of the village also gathered near the abandoned car. The villagers alleged that the foreign students had carved swear words against Indians on the dust on the car’s windshield. However, the students denied the allegation, stating they had video footage of the entire incident from the moment Ravi fled the spot.

“The video shows a local man writing the swear words abusing Indians. The police are attempting to nab this person,” said the statement from the police.The police said the issue stemmed from a three-year-old dispute between the people of Gauridad village and some foreign students after which the entire village had resolved not to give homes to African students on rent.

Based on Saturday’s incident, an application was filed at Kuvadva police station by the African students of the university and further investigation is underway. Naresh Jadeja, registrar of Marwadi University, told The Indian Express, “The incident that happened on Saturday night following a road accident was reported to the police by the students. Nobody was injured or harmed but it involved a verbal dispute. Since students were not at fault, we are with them. The police called both the parties and resolved the issue.” Inspector BP Rajya of Kuvadva Road police station said, “We have not converted the application into an FIR because the students decided against it in the larger interest of peace. However, we have recorded their statements as well as that of the car owner (who was later tracked down). We are still looking to apprehend the person who wrote the abuses on the car.”
reference_summary: A near-accident in Rajkot escalated into a physical altercation and accusations between a foreign student from Liberia and a local resident. The incident occurred on Saturday when Jefferson, a student at Marwadi University, almost collided with a car driven by Ravi in Gauridad village. After the near-miss, Ravi reportedly attacked Jefferson with a stick before fleeing the scene. Shortly afterward, a group of villagers accused the foreign students of writing offensive swear words on the car's windshield. However, the students denied the accusation, claiming to have video footage showing a local man writing the offensive words. The police are investigating the matter and attempting to apprehend the individual responsible for the graffiti. Although no FIR has been filed, the police recorded statements from both parties, and the issue is being resolved peacefully. The dispute is believed to be linked to a prior three-year-old conflict between Gauridad villagers and foreign students.

[DOC 1] PATNA: The Patna district administration on Saturday directed the primary and secondary sections of all private and government schools to keep the institutions closed on Monday and Tuesday in view of the ice-cold conditions prevailing in the state.Kumar said this arrangement would be there for a week after which the situation will be reviewed.

Icy westerly winds swept through Patna and its adjoining areas from Saturday morning and the sky was overcast. The sun could be seen only around noon, but the intensity of the sunlight too low. The minimum temperature recorded the wee hours was 10.9 degree Celsius.

Due to a heavy fog in Delhi, Air India's morning and evening flights were delayed by three hours.Both the Delhi-Patna flight and its return journey were delayed by three hours each. Even the evening flight from Delhi as well as its return were delayed by three hours.

The Sanjay Gandhi Biological Park authorities have taken steps to protect animals from the cold. Patna zoo deputy director Praveen Kumar said: "We have covered the cemented floors ( cages with straw for the comfort of animals.'

The cages of lion, tiger and deer have been provided with blowers and heaters.For animals living in the shade, a boundary has been created with the help of straws to guard them from the biting cold. Also, three sides of a bird cage have been covered with polythene sheets, Kumar added.He added that the administration will review the weather condition again on Tuesday.

Kumar further stated that due to the chilly winds, the district administration has made arrangements for bonfire at 16 places in the state capital. These are Yarpur Domkhana, Hartali Mor, IT roundabout, Dak Bungalow crossing, 'Rain basera' near Patna Museum, Bansghat, Karbigahiya, Mithapur Bus Stand, R-Block, Mahavir Temple gate, Reserve Bank of India, Ambedkar Bhawan at Nala Road, near PMCH emergency and children's wards, 'Rain basera' at Engineering College and Bankipore Bus Stand.

[DOC 1] After a historic 18-day sojourn to the International Space Station (ISS), astronaut Shubhanshu Shukla is likely to return to India during the week when the nation will celebrate the 78th Independence Day.

Shukla, who piloted the Axiom-4 mission, and his three crew mates : mission commander Peggy Whitson, and mission specialists Tibor Kapu and Slawosz Uznanski, returned to Earth on Wednesday. Following a picture-perfect splashdown off the California coast, the crew were ferried on a chopper to Houston for medical examination, mission debriefing and other procedures.

The Indian Express has learned from reliable sources at the Department of Space (DoS) that Group Captain Shukla is expected to arrive on August 14 or two-three days later.

Story continues below this ad

“He is expected to arrive in New Delhi. There are plans to arrange a grand reception for Group Captain Shukla in the presence of Prime Minister Narendra Modi,” an official said.

On Wednesday, President Droupadi Murmu and PM Modi had put out congratulatory messages to Shukla on social media platform ‘X’, welcoming him back to Earth after the successful mission.

Meanwhile, Uznanski of Poland representing the European Space Agency (ESA) reached Cologne Bonn in Germany on Thursday. He will undergo post-space mission debriefing and other mandatory activities in the next few days.

Meanwhile, Union minister Jitendra Singh said Group Captain Shubhanshu Shukla is expected to arrive in India by August 17 following a series of post-mission procedures.

Story continues below this ad

“There are certain SOPs to be followed… His rehabilitation, debriefing sessions and a series of discussions with Team ISRO. We might expect him in Delhi by August 17,” Singh told PTI video. Calling the mission “unprecedented”, Singh said the experiments conducted by Shukla during his stay in the orbital laboratory were closely linked to human survival and life in microgravity. “These experiments will be useful not just for Indians, but for all of humanity,” he said. “It is a moment of immense joy for India,” he said.

(With PTI inputs)

[DOC 1] Jamshedpur: Former CM and senior BJP leader Champai Soren
on Saturday held the state govt accountable for the death of
Mangal Munda, a direct descendant of tribal icon Birsa Munda,
citing critical delays in his medical treatment.
Speaking to media in Kandra, the Seraikela MLA strongly criticized
the healthcare system's response to Mangal's emergency. "The
health department's delayed response and failure to provide
timely treatment directly contributed to this tragic loss. Had the
health officials acted promptly, we could have saved his life,"
Champai stated.
Mangal Munda, the 45-year-old great-grandson of Birsa Munda,
suffered severe head injuries after falling from the roof of a passenger vehicle in Khunti on Nov 25. Initially
admitted to Khunti's sadar hospital, he was later transferred to Rims, Ranchi, where he died in the early hours of
Nov 29.
"This is a clear case of systemic negligence," Champai emphasized. "It's particularly devastating that we failed to
save the life of someone connected to our revered hero Birsa Munda, whom we all worship."
The former CM also addressed the current political situation, particularly the delay in forming the Hemant Soren's
cabinet. "The fact that cabinet ministers haven't been sworn in yet indicates significant issues within the INDIA
bloc alliance," he observed.
Champai has announced plans to travel to Ranchi for consultations with party leaders to finalize their strategy for
challenging the government, both during the upcoming four-day special assembly session starting Dec 9 and in
subsequent political engagements.
reference_summary: Former CM and BJP leader Champai Soren held the state government accountable for the death of Mangal Munda, a direct descendant of Birsa Munda, due to delays in his medical treatment. Mangal, who suffered head injuries after falling from a vehicle in Khunti, was initially treated at Khunti's hospital before being transferred to RIMS, Ranchi, where he died on Nov 29. Soren criticized the health department's delayed response, calling it systemic negligence. He also addressed political issues, particularly the delay in forming Hemant Soren's cabinet, and announced plans to consult with party leaders on their strategy for challenging the government.

[DOC 1] A number of innovations, including a solar-powered driverless bus, will be on display at the upcoming Indian Science Congress which will be inaugurated by the Prime Minister Narendra Modi on January 3.

Renewable energy is expected to be the key focus of the five-day 106th edition of the Science Congress with the theme 'Future India: Science and Technology'.

The Congress, which will bring innovators and scientists under one roof, will be held on the premises of Lovely Professional University (LPU).

The University will showcase its own innovation in the form of a solar-powered driverless bus. The eco-friendly heavy vehicle will ferry passengers to the aerodrome, housing societies, industrial complexes, and educational institutions.

University spokesperson said that the design of the solar bus has been made in accordance with the available Indian infrastructure. The bus, which will cost Rs six lakh each, can have seating capacity between 10 and 30 and can run at the maximum speed of 30 km per hour.

“We are very happy to design a completely driverless and eco-friendly bus to welcome PM Modi. If his schedule and security arrangements permit, we would love to give him a tour of our campus in the bus,” said the project head Mandeep Singh.

Chancellor Ashok Mittal said that the driverless bus is an example of LPU students being at the forefront of technology.

“Some other interesting projects done by LPU students include Flying Farmer, a wireless sensor device, exclusively used in farming and field survey, Formula one car and Go-karts,” he added.
reference_summary: The Indian Science Congress, scheduled to be inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, will feature various innovations, including a solar-powered driverless bus. The event, themed "Future India: Science and Technology," will focus on renewable energy. Lovely Professional University (LPU) will showcase its solar-powered driverless bus, designed to transport passengers to various destinations. The bus, costing Rs six lakh each, has a seating capacity between 10 and 30 and can reach a maximum speed of 30 km per hour. The LPU Chancellor praised students for being at the forefront of technology with innovations like the driverless bus.

[DOC 1] Tarsem Singh’s indulgent epic, produced by Spike Jonze and David Fincher, was little seen on its original release in 2006, and now gets a rerelease in a 4K restoration on the Mubi streaming platform. It’s certainly worth noticing, with its Gilliamesque surrealism, and its setting in Rajasthan, north-western India, offers wonderful landscapes. Its beguiling set pieces feature Justine Waddell playing some deadpan comedy as a gloriously costumed princess – although I have to admit that in general the film’s rather placid, stately, fantasy style can be exasperatingly inert.

The scene is Los Angeles in the early years of silent pictures; Lee Pace plays Roy, a stuntman who is now seriously, perhaps permanently, injured. He is laid up in hospital and deeply depressed after a dangerous fall filming a movie whose lead actress was once his girlfriend, but has now left him for the vapid male star. Roy is befriended by a little Romanian girl from the neighbouring children’s ward; this is Alexandria (played by Catinca Untaru, whose English dialogue is sometimes a little indistinct). Kindly, Roy offers to tell the wide-eyed Alexandria an epic story of adventure featuring five heroes battling a hateful governor, and the story comes to life before our eyes with Roy and Alexandria appearing in it and some whimsical muddling up of Indians and Native Americans.
But Roy has an ulterior motive with this Scheherazade-type storytelling; he wants to take Alexandria into his confidence so that she will steal a bottle of morphine for him, perhaps so that he can take his own life. Waddell plays a nurse who appears to be having an affair with a doctor, and she appears in the story as the princess who is engaged to be married to the warriors’ enemy, but falls for Roy. There are some startling images and the film has a distinct, odd flavour of its own.
reference_summary:
Tarsem Singh’s The Fall (2006) is an ambitious, visually stunning epic that blends surreal fantasy with poignant human drama. Set in 1920s Los Angeles, it tells the story of Roy (Lee Pace), a stuntman who is bedridden and depressed after a debilitating injury. He befriends Alexandria, a young girl in the hospital, and begins to tell her a fantastical tale about five heroes on a quest to defeat an evil governor. The story unfolds as a vivid, dreamlike fantasy, with breathtaking set pieces and stunning landscapes, notably in Rajasthan, India.

While the film is visually captivating, with Gilliam-esque surrealism and lush costuming, its slow, dreamlike pacing can feel inert at times. The film also explores darker themes, as Roy's storytelling serves an ulterior motive—he is trying to manipulate Alexandria into stealing morphine for him, possibly to end his life. The film blends fantasy and reality, with characters from the hospital appearing in the story Roy narrates. Justine Waddell plays both a hospital nurse and a princess in Roy’s tale, adding layers to the narrative.

The Fall is a unique, visually rich film with a distinct style and emotional depth, though its languid pace and introspective tone may not resonate with everyone.

[DOC 1] new delhi: keith vaz, britain's minister of state for foreign and commonwealth affairs, will fly in to india tuesday to
a raging controversy. at the heart of the issue is britain's announcement of a pilot scheme to facilitate short term
visas to the uk against a bond of 10,000 pounds. the experimental project is to be tried out in india and
bangladesh later this year. the proposal has already led to anger in bangladesh where vaz, on an official visit, tried
to assuage feelings by saying the scheme is not aimed at discriminating against people from south asia.
moreover, no one will be forced to pay the 10,000 pounds. ``it is a test case; if it doesn't work, it'll be dropped,'' he
added. the assurance, however, hasn't allayed concerns in india. new delhi has reacted sharply to the move. ``we
are ascertaining facts about this issue. the information we have at present is through press reports as we have not
been extended the courtesy of being consulted,'' r.s. jassal, spokesman of the ministry of external affairs, said on
monday. he went on to add: ``it is our expectation that in consular matters any new rules or guidelines adopted
by a country should be implemented across the board on a non-discriminatory basis for citizens of all countries.''
the spokesman felt the new rules should not be applied to south asia alone. he ended with the warning that india
would retaliate in similar terms for british nationals seeking visas to this country: ``we would like to clarify that in
the event that such rules and guidelines are instituted, we reserve the right to take reciprocal action.'' british
diplomats in new delhi are surprised at india's strong reaction. they believe the issue has been misunderstood
reference_summary:
Keith Vaz, Britain's Minister of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs, is set to visit India amid a growing controversy surrounding the UK’s announcement of a pilot scheme for short-term visas. The scheme, which would require a bond of £10,000, is set to be tested in India and Bangladesh. The proposal has sparked anger in Bangladesh, and Vaz attempted to reassure the public by stating that the scheme was not intended to discriminate against South Asians, clarifying that participation in the scheme would be voluntary and subject to review.

India has reacted strongly, with the Ministry of External Affairs expressing concerns that they were not consulted about the scheme. They raised the issue of fairness, stating that such policies should be applied equally across all countries and should not be targeted at South Asia. India also warned that they might retaliate with similar measures for British nationals seeking visas to India. British diplomats in New Delhi are surprised by the strong reaction, believing the issue has been misunderstood.

[DOC 1] The Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) has big expansion plans for 2024. It plans to induct 2,000 new buses, including 500 e-buses, and to also introduce VTMS (Vehicle Tracking & Monitoring System), a mobile app, and cashless travel this year. Anbu Kumar, Managing Director, KSRTC, said that the KSRTC will add 20 Ambari Utsav, 20 Airavat Club Class, 100 Pallaki buses which fall in the non-AC sleeper category, 1000 point to point Karnataka Sarige buses and 500 electric buses. Apart from this Mr. Kumar added that 1000 refurbished buses will be added to the fleet in 2024. Following the launch of Shakti that provides free travel to women in State-owned non-premium transport corporation buses, there’s been a significant demand for KSRTC buses, particularly in rural areas. A senior official said that the plan to induct 1000 Karnataka Sarige buses will improve rural connectivity in the State and it will also help the beneficiaries of the scheme. After the Karnataka government launched the Shakti scheme, the four corporations (KSRTC, the BMTC, the NWKRTC, and the KKRTC) planned to procure 3,888 new buses. Currently, the four RTCs operate 23,989 buses across the State with an average run of 65.02 lakh kilometres per day.Meanwhile, it is not clear as to how many buses will be taken off roads this year in light of the recent High Court order, which said KSRTC should obtain fitness certificate for its buses from the Regional Transport Officers (RTOs) every year. Cashless travelIn response to passengers’ growing demand for a cashless travel experience, KSRTC is set to transition to a cashless system in 2024. Mr. Kumar said, “We plan to introduce cashless payment options, allowing passengers to use UPI, ATM, debit, or credit cards to make ticket payments.”The corporation has outlined plans to prioritise the enhancement of information technology. To benefit passengers, it aims to implement VTMS (Vehicle Tracking & Monitoring System) across its fleet and is scheduled to launch a dedicated KSRTC mobile app this year. According to Mr. Kumar, the ‘Namma Cargo’ parcel services, launched last month, are set to expand from the current fleet of 20 trucks to 500 by the end of the year.Meanwhile, the KSRTC has also waived 10,364 disciplinary cases against employees with minimal penalties, facilitating the return of 425 drivers to work. Additionally, the corporation has secured 50 national and international awards in the year 2023, according to officials. The Corporation recently wrapped up the ‘Labour Welfare Year’ in 2023, implementing initiatives focused on improving the welfare of its employees. During the year, ₹1 crore was allocated to the families of deceased employees as relief. 
 ‘Pallakki‘ sleeper bus launched by KSRTC today infront of Vidhana Soudha in Bengaluru.
| Photo Credit: SUDHAKARA JAIN
reference_summary: The Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) is set for significant expansion in 2024, with plans to introduce 2,000 new buses, including 500 e-buses. The corporation will also implement a Vehicle Tracking & Monitoring System, a mobile app, and cashless travel options. The addition of various bus types, such as Ambari Utsav and Airavat Club Class, aims to enhance rural connectivity and cater to the demand following the success of the Shakti scheme. KSRTC is focusing on improving IT infrastructure, expanding services like 'Namma Cargo,' and prioritizing employee welfare, including resolving disciplinary cases and receiving numerous awards in 2023.

[DOC 1] Hyderabad, Jan 2 (PTI) Union Minister and Telangana BJP president G Kishan Reddy on Tuesday sought to know why Chief Minister A Revanth Reddy hadn’t written a letter to the Centre seeking a CBI inquiry on alleged corruption in the Kaleshwaram project in the state. HT Image

Speaking to reporters here, Kishan Reddy wondered if there is any "tacit" understanding between the Congress government in the state and the BRS party on the issue, through meditation of AIMIM.

Wrap up the year gone by & gear up for 2024 with HT! Click here

"When in Opposition, the Congress leaders demanded a CBI inquiry into the issue. Today, why is the chief minister (Revanth Reddy) not writing a letter to the Centre seeking a CBI probe? Does the Congress government sincerely want an inquiry into the Kaleshwaram project or not? Do they want the culprits to be punished or not?" Kishan Reddy asked.

"I want to know whether the chief minister has any sincerity. The biggest scam of the BRS government was the Kaleshwaram project. Are you willing to order a CBI inquiry? Would you write a letter (to CBI)," the Telangana BJP chief asked.

During the assembly polls (last year), the Congress claimed that if voted to power, it would order an inquiry on "corruption" deeds including projects undertaken by the then BRS government, he said.

The previous government claimed the Kaleshwaram project as an engineering marvel and the largest lift irrigation project. They also said that concrete used in the project was equivalent to that of seven 'Burj Khalifa' in Dubai and steel was equivalent to that of 15 'Eiffel Tower' in Paris, he said.

The piers of the Medigadda barrage of the mega Kaleshwaram Lift Irrigation Scheme 'sinking' shook the state in October 2023 as it snowballed into a major controversy and a key election issue. The National Dam Safety Authority (NDSA) had found that the barrage was severely compromised, rendering it useless unless fully rehabilitated.

Kishan Reddy asked what is the future of Kaleshwaram project and the Telangana people and what is the fate of ₹1 lakh crore spent on the project.

The Medigadda barrage was a lifeline to the Kaleshwaram project, he said, adding that the NDSA also visited it and highlighted some of the key issues of the project. They sought some more details from the state government. However, replies were given to only 11 of the 20 issues, the BJP leader said.

"Why is the Congress government dilly-dallying on the corruption involved in the construction of the project? Will they accept NDSA suggestions? When they (Congress) were in opposition, Revanth Reddy wanted to know what the Central government and Prime Minister Narendra Modi were doing. Now there is a necessity to spell out the state government’s stand on the issue," he said.

Earlier, when the BJP demanded an inquiry, the then Telangana Chief Minister K Chandrasekhar Rao did not approve the CBI probe, Kishan Reddy said.

[DOC 1] At the Congress’s Jilla Kartavya Sammelan in Nuh on Tuesday, former Haryana chief minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda announced ‘Ghar Ghar Congress’, a door-to-door campaign to discuss their poll pitch.
Speaking on a wide range of issues, the Opposition leader said if Congress comes to power, they would ensure Rs 6,000 for old age pension. Currently, the Haryana government disburses Rs 5,538 to 17 lakh beneficiaries.
“We will provide gas cylinders at Rs 500 against the current Rs 1,100,” he said. When the Congress government is formed in the state, 300 units of free electricity will be given, Hooda said as a poll pitch ahead of the 2024 Haryana Legislative Assembly election scheduled to be held on or before October to elect all MLAs.
On the treatment meted out to wrestlers, Hooda said, “We saw what our daughters had to face at Jantar Mantar and if we come to power, we will ensure the appointment of sportspersons to senior posts like DSP.” For OBCs, the creamy layer limit will be increased from Rs 6 to Rs 10 lakh, he promised.
On the three-day strike launched by truck, bus and tanker drivers to protest against the stringent jail and fine regulations under the newly-launched Bharatiya Nyay Sanhita (BNS) for hit-and-run cases, Hooda said, “New law was made without consultation with drivers and will be rectified when the Congress government is formed,” Hooda said.
A group of protesters met the former chief minister to air their grievances and submitted a representation on Tuesday.
Mahendragarh MLA Rao Dan Singh said, “Mewat is an area where at least one member of the household is a driver and this comes as a blow to them.” He added that Haryana is disappointed with theBJP-JJP government and will soon vote for Hooda.
“Till 2014, Haryana was number one in per capita income, per capita investment, job creation, law and order, welfare of farmers, poor and businessmen,” Hooda said, adding that the BJP-JJP government gave nothing to Haryana, except unemployment, misery and destruction.
Captain Ajay Yadav, who contested Lok Sabha elections from the Gurgaon constituency consisting of Nuh, said Mewat only knows the language of brotherhood while BJP speaks the language of hatred.
Addressing the Congress workers meeting organised by the party’s deputy leader in the Assembly Aftab Ahmed, MLAs Mohammad Ilyas, and Maman Khan, Hooda said Haryana has rejected the politics of division practised by the BJP.
Speaking toThe Indian Expresson the cow protection law in the state, Hooda said it is the law even though it has been called arbitrary and unconstitutional for the powers it gives private entities apart from the police.
In his address, Hooda said BJP-JJP do politics of division only in the name of religion, while brotherhood and development form the basis of Congress’s politics.
“The present government is trying to destroy the medical college built in Mewat during the Congress government. The hospital has neither doctors nor medicines. Centuries of brotherhood, which was not broken even during the partition of 1947, was tested under the present government,” he said.
Hooda did not comment on the possibility of the INDIA alliance in the state
Aiswarya Raj is a correspondent with The Indian Express who covers South Haryana. An alumna of Asian College of Journalism and the University of Kerala, she started her career at The Indian Express as a sub-editor in the Delhi city team. In her current position, she reports from Gurgaon and covers the neighbouring districts. She likes to tell stories of people and hopes to find moorings in narrative journalism.... Read More
reference_summary: Former Haryana chief minister Bhupinder Singh Hooda announced a 'Ghar Ghar Congress' campaign during his speech at the Jilla Kartavya Sammelan. Promising old age pensions of Rs 6,000 instead of the current Rs 5,538 and halving gas cylinder costs from Rs 1,100 to Rs 500, Hooda aimed at gaining public support ahead of the legislative elections. The Congress promised free electricity for three units daily under their government's regime. They pledged better treatment for wrestlers by appointing sportspersons in senior posts and increasing OBC creamy layer exemption to Rs 10 lakh from Rs 6 lakhs. Hooda also criticized the current BJP-JJP rule, claiming it led to unemployment and misery since its tenure began until his party's victory in 2014 when he was Chief Minister of Haryana—an era marked by growth across various sectors. He vowed to restore a sense of brotherhood that allegedly broke during the present government, which also faced criticism for handling cow protection laws and medical college conditions poorly. The Congress did not comment on potential alliances with other parties like INDIA in upcoming elections. Ajay Yadav criticized BJP's divisive politics while Hooda emphasized brotherhood as the cornerstone of his party’s ethos, contrasting it to religion-centric policies seen under current rule.

[DOC 1] Investigation into the alleged spurious cancer drugs racket, busted earlier this month by the Crime Branch, has revealed that a substantial quantity of these fake medicines made their way to India through Kathmandu in Nepal, officers said.

Police said they have zeroed in on a supplier in Nepal who would be nabbed soon.

The main accused in the case, Naveen Arya, remains absconding. Arya, who runs a shop at Bhagirath Palace in Chandni Chowk, claiming to sell drugs to treat cancer and hepatitis, was arrested by another unit of the Crime Branch last year in a similar case. He remained in prison for 4-5 months before being granted regular bail. It didn’t take long for him to engage in the same business and operate a network, this time from another route, said police.

Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP) Crime Vikram Singh said that as per the report of the drug inspector, the medicines are fake. “We have also sent the seized drugs to the forensics laboratory for examination. A detailed report is awaited,” said the DCP.

A team led by DCP Singh and comprising Assistant CP Yashpal, Inspector Ashish Sharma, Sub-Inspectors (SIs) Prakash and Guman, and Assistant SI Sandeep Chawla, among others, has been working on the case.

Officers said that the role of Arya’s wife is also under scrutiny, adding that her mobile phone was being used to take online orders.

Police said the fact that the syndicate dealt only in cash is making it difficult to establish the money trail. “There are no bills as well; Arya took orders online and spoke to people on WhatsApp, leaving no trace. We request people to come forward, in case they have purchased drugs like these online, so that we can unearth the chain. We are also looking at cases registered in different states to see if there are any links or possible similarities,” said Singh.

Notably, Arya had earlier applied for anticipatory bail in a city court, which was rejected. The next date of hearing is in July.

In the first week of June, Delhi Police claimed to have busted a “well-organised racket that sold spurious, unauthorised, and unregistered cancer drugs” to patients. Six people were arrested in three simultaneous raids — at Laxmi Nagar, Budh Vihar, and Chandni Chowk — and counterfeit medication worth several lakhs was seized, police said.

Police said the accused targeted cancer patients through social media groups, claiming to offer expensive drugs at discounted rates.

Later, two more persons, who were allegedly supplying the counterfeit cancer vials to people in Delhi-NCR, were also arrested. It was during the questioning of these two accused that the police learnt about the drugs coming through the Kathmandu route, said officers.
reference_summary:
Delhi Police’s investigation into a spurious cancer drugs racket busted earlier this month has revealed that fake medicines were being routed into India via Kathmandu, Nepal, according to officials. A supplier in Nepal has been identified and is likely to be arrested soon.

The main accused, Naveen Arya, who previously ran a cancer drug shop in Chandni Chowk’s Bhagirath Palace, remains absconding. He was earlier jailed in a similar case and resumed operations post-bail using a new network and route. His wife’s involvement is also being probed, as her mobile was used to process online orders.

The racket functioned entirely on cash, with no billing or paper trail, making financial tracking difficult. Arya used WhatsApp to take orders, further complicating evidence collection. Authorities are urging potential victims to come forward to help trace the distribution chain.

Six arrests have been made so far, with counterfeit cancer drugs worth lakhs seized in raids at Laxmi Nagar, Budh Vihar, and Chandni Chowk. Further arrests revealed that the Kathmandu route was used for smuggling.

Forensic tests on the seized drugs are underway, and the next court hearing on Arya’s rejected bail plea is scheduled for July.

[DOC 1] Terror, whatever the source, is a threat to India. Let’s not use it for political one-upmanship.
Negative politics has derailed what should have been a meaningful debate into the challenge emerging from recently unearthed terror groups who seem to have been behind the Mecca masjid blast in Hyderabad in 2007, the outrage at Ajmer Sharif dargah, Malegaon in 2008 and last year in Goa. By seeking to dub these outfits as saffron, the Congress, notably All India Congress Committe general secretary Digvijaya Singh, has pitted these subversive elements against so-called Islamic fundamentalists. By dragging in an emotive issue like the call from the late Hemant Karkare who allegedly expressed fears that he was the target of ‘saffron’ terrorists, Mr Singh has further vitiated the atmosphere.

It is possible that Karkare was apprehensive of threats to his life, but one must question Mr Singh’s motive for making this public at a time when investigations are on into the activities of people like Swami Assemanand and his cohorts who seem to have links with several terror attacks. It is condemnable that few seem inclined to denounce terror for what it is instead of politicising it. The BJP appears to be soft-pedalling the issue, perhaps worried about reactions from its parent body the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh which has torn a strip off Mr Singh on the Karkare issue. Terror, whatever the source, has become a grave threat to India’s peace and stability. The home minister has rightly been putting into place several agencies that will tackle this menace in a more comprehensive and coordinated manner. All political parties need to work together on this issue.

Terrorists do not owe their loyalties to any legitimate political formation, a lesson we should have learnt from the incidents in neighbouring Pakistan. To say that some terrorists may be acting in the name of Hindutva cannot be condemned as anti-national. Terrorists have demonstrated that they can strike at will and are able to take advantage of political dissonance of the sort we are witnessing now. Such irresponsible talk can only fuel a fear psychosis and whip up negative public sentiments. A carnage of the magnitude of 26/11 should have galvanised people across the political spectrum to treat terror as the most difficult challenge India faces. Today we have vibrant intelligence-sharing arrangements with several countries, most notably the US. But, we cannot expect people to believe we are serious about the fight against terror if it is reduced to political one-upmanship. Terror has many faces but certainly not different colours.
reference_summary: The article emphasizes the need for a united front against terrorism in India, irrespective of its origin, rather than using it for political gains. The author criticizes the Congress party, particularly All India Congress Committee general secretary Digvijaya Singh, for labeling certain terror groups as "saffron" and bringing in emotive issues, such as the late Hemant Karkare's alleged concerns about being a target of "saffron" terrorists. The article calls for denouncing terrorism as a grave threat to India's peace and stability, urging all political parties to work together to address this menace. It emphasizes the importance of a comprehensive and coordinated approach to counterterrorism.
