[DOC 1] In an interview with ET Now, Mark Mobius, Chairman, Templeton EM Group, talks about QE2, emerging and frontier markets as well as sectors they are still excited about. Excerpts:

Over the last two weeks, since the QE2 announcement, there is talk of a whole lot of money going to be infused into the US financial system. There is one argument that the large part of that money is going to flow into emerging markets. Would you believe that is a little exaggerated or is that really going to be the case?

Mark Mobius: Would not say the majority is going to flow into the emerging markets, but a significant amount is flowing into not only emerging markets but ETFs and into commodities, and into all kinds of instruments that will pay or promise to pay a higher rate of return than what people are getting on US treasuries.

Given what you just said, should markets like India start beginning to worry about potential bubbles being created in various asset classes?

Mark Mobius: Yes, I think that is certainly a possibility. We do not see it yet, but we have to be very cautious. The good news is that this money, that has been ploughing into not only our funds but other emerging market funds and into the markets, has been largely absorbed by new IPOs and secondary issues. Last year we calculated about 260 billion in IPOs and secondary issues. This year, it will be double that amount to over 450 billion. So this money is coming in and is being absorbed to a great extent. But if it continues, then valuations may rise to unreasonable levels.

There is an argument that QE2 is only going to drive up valuations in emerging markets, you do not need to yet start worrying about asset bubbles being created. Those same people actually believe that by the middle of next year the US economy is still going to be in pretty bad shape, the Fed is going to hold back on raising rates and they might actually push ahead with QE3. Do you see that likelihood?

That is a possibility. But the criticism that has been received regarding QE2 and also the lessons that have been learnt, has resulted what has happened in the last two years. The administration is going to change course and take measures that more directly impact job creation and you all know what that is. It is helping small and medium size business, cutting down on government intervention, etc. there are lot of measures they can take without throwing money from helicopter, so to speak.
QE2 has also meant that yields on US treasuries will decline. We are already seeing that happen. Do you expect that US fixed income investors on account of lower yields will actually start beginning to redeploy resources and possibly redeploy some of that money into equities?

Mark Mobius: Yes, but more importantly, they will deploy them into emerging market bonds as well because some investors are dedicated bond investors and they cannot go into equities by definition of their mandate. So they will go into emerging market bonds because they found that first of all emerging market bonds pay a higher rate and secondly, they can make money on the currency.

This is a very interesting, unusual and different scenario that we had in past years where anybody from the US or Europe looking at emerging market bonds would only buy Euro or US dollar denominated bonds. Now they are buying local currency bonds which by the way is very good for emerging markets because it means they have an opportunity to develop their bond market. So you are going to see more of that and of course equities will get their share.

You have got countries in emerging regions coming out and trying to check the rise of their currencies which the US has issues with. Should the US be objecting to that when it believes that pumping up its economy through QE is the best way forward? None of the emerging economies are complaining about the US going ahead with QE2. Why should the US complain about them checking their currency rises?

You are right, the shoe should fit on both feet because emerging markets naturally are concerned about the appreciation of their currencies. The only way they can avoid appreciation is by buying US dollars, US treasury bonds. So they end up with these piles of US treasury bonds which is a risk in itself by the way because the valuations of those bonds may not hold up.

But there is no reason why the US should be complaining about these countries trying to prevent a rapid increase in the value of their currencies. In some cases of course many of these emerging market currencies are still undervalued. Yes, countries like Brazil since the beginning of the year have seen a 20-30% appreciation of their currency against US dollar. But if you go down a list of these countries, you see many of them are undervalued on price parity basis.

Even if China and other emerging markets actually do allow their currencies to appreciate and to go up, is it actually going to address the global imbalances that the US and the other OECD markets keep talking about? The big advantage that emerging economies have is not their currencies, it is their much cheaper labour markets.

An appreciation of the Yuan/renminbi in China and other currencies could exacerbate the problems in the US because the products that are being made in these countries - particularly in China and India – and services provided by Indian firms are keeping inflation in America and Europe down. You walk into a Wal-Mart or any retail outlet in America or Europe, you see it is full of goods from emerging markets - particularly from China.
So a rapid appreciation of the Chinese currency will mean that retail prices in these countries will go up. That is not good because it means inflation will go up and they will not be able to carry out the programmes that they are trying to achieve. So we have to be very careful in allowing these currencies to appreciate too rapidly. A gradual appreciation is good as this allows people to adjust, but a rapid appreciation could present real problems.

There are some people who actually believe that the current large capital flows into Asia are going to lead to the creation of asset bubbles and that Asia could be headed towards in 1997 like situation. Is that something you would go with?

Of course, as I really do feel that bubbles will come. It is a nature of these markets because people do get carried away. The mere fact that you are asking this question now means that people are thinking about that and they are very aware of the danger. Therefore, probably, they will now not allow it to happen. But given the few years and the continued bullishness in these markets, you could see a sort of mania beginning again - like we saw with the subprime and with the dotcom bubble. The problem nowadays is that the volatility increases much - much greater because the amount of money out there is much greater and the derivative market is much bigger and that creates volatility.

While things do not look so worrisome at this point, in time surely there are pockets in Asia that are beginning to overheat. Which regions and asset classes would you be worried about at this point of time?

It is very difficult to see any particular region or asset class that is overheated at this stage of the game. It is true some smaller markets have moved up dramatically, but you must remember that the valuations have not gone down because the earnings per share of companies have gone up a lot. So if you look at around the price earnings or price to book or dividend yield, I cannot think of any market that is really overheated to the extent that I would run in the other direction immediately.
Talking about India, would you worry about valuations given the current levels that the markets are at?

No, I do not think so. There are still lots of opportunities here. If you look at historical numbers, historical price earnings ratios look expensive. But if you look forward what these companies are going to do next year, the year after, the growth rates are very high in many of these countries and the structure of this society is going to mean the take off stage for many levels of the society is near at hand.
In India, which sectors are you still excited about and which sectors would you be a little worried about?

One of the sectors we are particularly excited about is consumer sector - anything to do with consumers. We love the consumers because there are more of them in Asia, begin in China, begin here in India and their per captia income is moving up at a fast pace because we have seen a deceleration of population growth and an acceleration of economic growth. So if you are growing at 7-8% in real terms and your population is growing, let’s say, 1%, then obviously per capita income is moving up. So that is one scenario and one area that we really like.

The other is commodities. We believe that commodity prices will continue to trend upwards, whether it is palladium, whether it is platinum, whether it is coal, whether it is oil, nickel - you name it. We think these prices will trend upwards. So we want to be exposed to that sector. In terms of sectors that we would not want to be in, given the appreciation of currencies or the imminent appreciation of currencies, export-oriented companies are something that we have to be careful about. I am not saying that all of them should not be bought, but we have to look at those carefully.

You did talk about being bullish on commodities and consumers, how about the infrastructure space, how about banking? Do you believe those sectors have been a little overbought and that at the moment you do not see value there?

Banking, we are in and we like because of consumer banking. When I state consumers, it covers a pretty wide spectrum and consumer banks are very interesting because in many of these countries, many people do not even have bank accounts. So there is a long way to go in that regard. Talking about infrastructure, we have to pick on a sector by sector, country by country basis because any of these infrastructure plays are regulated normally and unless you have got an iron-clad contract which defines how the investors are going to get paid, you can get into real trouble. So that is something you have to watch.

When you take a bird’s eye view of the opportunity that the consumer space offers for banking, it does look extremely lucrative. But we have seen banks in India take extremely long time in actually breaking even on their consumer operations. Is that something that worries you because we have had some banks that have been in the business for more than 10 years and they still continue to lose money in that space?

Yes, there has been real problem with some of these banks. Part of that is regulation. In other words, limits on interest rates means that they have to be very careful who they are lending to. If they have high risk and they cannot high risk consumers and borrowers and cannot raise the rates to cover the non-performing loans, then you have a problem. I think a lot of this has been related to inefficiencies within the banks. Many of the banks have not carted on how to make their operations more efficient. But it is coming and we have seen in many instances that banks in India are really beginning to change the way they operate and become more efficient.
Do you believe the manufacturing sector looks a little worrisome right now simply because of the huge pick up or huge rise that they are going to see in input costs?

Exactly, that is something we have to be very careful and that is the reason why I did not mention manufacturing. It is a sector which we would want to necessarily be very heavy on - depending on individual company and the individual opportunity. But given the cost, a lot of these companies are getting squeezed. On the one hand, they have lots of competition. So their selling prices cannot be raised. On the other side, the inputs - the commodities that they use - are rising in price. So it presents a real opportunity for the commodity producers, but not one for the people that are consuming.

A number of overseas investors into India talk about their concerns about governance practices with Indian companies. Are you happy with the progress that you have seen with governance practices at Indian companies, especially the promoter or rather family-run companies?

Generally speaking, India is quite good. One of the reasons for this is that the Indian companies are articulate. The command that Indian managers have of language - of English language in particular and language in general - and their ability to express themselves really well augurs well for communicating their systems in the way they operate and this is good for corporate governance. So this is a good exchange of information between the stakeholders and share holders and the company.

So generally speaking, India is no worse than other countries including the US. Corporate governance in the US has not been too good. But generally speaking, India has higher marks than many-many other countries and of course there is always a desire to see improvement and more transparency. Transparency is not so much a problem in India. It is more the majority shareholders wanting to do things their own way and not thinking about what is good for overall for the minority investors. But they are willing to listen and that is a very good sign.

We are seeing pockets of selling across Asia by foreign investors. Do you believe foreign investors at this point in time are beginning to worry a little about valuations that they want to take some cash off the table?

Mark Mobius: They always worry. Bull markets are built on a wall of worry. You see that all the time people say ‘Oh! God it has gone up by 30%-40%-50%, let me take some profits’. So you have that these corrections along the way. That does not change the basic scenario of a secular bull market that we are in. These bull markets last longer than bear markets. This is one of the things that we have noticed with emerging markets. Generally since 1988, we have had 3 major bear markets and by bear markets I mean a decline of 30% or more. But these bear markets were very short in duration. The bull markets last much, much longer and I believe that is the case now.
If the US does raise interest rates, would you worry that there is going to be a bit of a pullback in emerging markets by the middle of next year?

Yes, if you have a situation where interest rates in US treasuries move up dramatically and thereby impact the rest of the world, then of course there will be concern. But we must look at the record. If you look at the record of interest rates - both real and nominal – and markets, the correlation is not that high. So we have to be careful because you cannot take a one variable like that and say okay interest rates go up then markets will be in trouble, no. But there will be certainly some concerns and you will wonder ‘Hey! is this over because interest rates in the US are going up’.

If that does happen and when that does happen, would you change your view on exporter companies out of Asia because currencies will have dropped in reaction to US interest rate hikes?

Of course yes, if the currencies – let’s say the US dollar – get substantially stronger and the emerging market currencies stay where they are, there will be a boom in exports. It goes same for Europe, for the Euro. That is certainly something we have to look at - whether it is going to happen and what the probabilities are. I am not so sure.

Would you say that Japan is going to be the biggest beneficiary of an interest rate hike in the US?

Yes, they would probably benefit from that happening. Japan is now benefiting more from China as exports from Japan are greater to China than to the US or to Europe. What happens in China is going to have more impact on what happens in Japan. If China is able to continue exports to the US, that indirectly helps Japan.

You have been a pioneer in identifying some of the attractive frontier markets across the world. You have talked about Nigeria being an extremely attractive market. Which are the frontier markets are you seeing value in now?

The one that really has good value is Vietnam. The problem in Vietnam is that liquidity is very-very poor. Kazakhstan is another market which we think is quite attractive. In Africa, there are many countries like Botswana, Ghana, Kenya and in North Africa you have Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt which are very interesting. In the Middle Eastern markets, you have got Dubai, Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi - these are very interesting markets. It is quite amazing to see how many markets there are in the frontier arena. In Romania, we have just established an office in Bucharest and that is a very interesting market as well.
Would you agree that frontier markets, while they do look attractive from the outside, the ability to go in as a large investor is not there because these markets are so small, so illiquid and so over regulated?

I would not say about over regulated. Many of these are under regulated. There is not a problem on regulation so much in these markets. Since there are so many of these markets, we are able to nibble at all these different times in different ways and our frontier markets have grown dramatically. We are now managing over 800 million and nearing the 900 million mark. We haven’t had any problem in investing the money. So it is quite remarkable how these markets have blossomed and they will be growing with more IPOs and more activity.

You did mention about $900 million in frontier markets, what percentage is that of your total portfolio allocation and do you see that $900 million progressively increasing over the next few years?

It is increasing, this amount is increasing. Of course, it is a very small amount of the total that we have in emerging markets. So it is a fraction of what we have.

There are some who argue that frontier markets aren’t too different from emerging markets because volatility in these markets is - if not identical - fairly close to each other. You have the issues of liquidity, you have the issues of getting in and getting out of those markets not being so easy. Is that something you agree with or would you identify frontier markets as a different class and emerging markets as a different class?

Frontier markets of course is a subset of emerging markets. But they are very different. The correlation between frontier markets and emerging markets is very low. Unlike emerging markets and developed markets, the correlation is much higher and the behaviour is very different. It is quite remarkable how different they are. So that will probably be the case for sometime to come because markets like Nigeria, Kenya, Vietnam, Kazakhstan are really new and growing markets and their behaviour is going to be very different from the developed and emerging markets.
reference_summary: The influx of money post QE2 is significant, impacting emerging markets and commodities. Concerns arise about potential asset bubbles in India. The US may not object to emerging markets checking currency rises, as it benefits from their bond purchases. While an appreciation of emerging market currencies might not address global imbalances, a rapid rise could lead to inflation in the US and Europe. Potential asset bubbles in Asia are a concern, and the volatility is higher due to increased money and a larger derivative market. However, a gradual currency appreciation is seen as positive.

[DOC 1] Virat Kohli on Monday backed newly-appointed Royal Challengers Bengaluru (RCB) captain Rajat Patidar to lead the franchise for many years. Kohli himself led the franchise for more than a decade before relinquishing the captaincy after the 2021 IPL season.
“This guy is going to lead you for a long time. He is going to do a great job. He has got everything that is required (to succeed),” Kohli said in his address to RCB’s loyal fans at the team’s Unbox event here on Monday.
“It feels amazing to be back. The excitement and happiness is like every other season. I have been here for 18 years and absolutely love RCB. We have an amazing squad this time around. Lot of talent in the team. I am personally very excited about this season,” Kohli added.
Patidar, who succeeded Faf du Plessis as captain after the South African was released ahead of the IPL 2025 auction, said it was an honor to lead RCB. “Legends like Virat bhai, Ab de Villiers, Chris Gayle have played for RCB. I grew up watching them. From the start I have loved the franchise a lot. I am more happy that I got a new role to lead one of the biggest teams (in T20 cricket),” said Patidar, who has also played for India.
The Indore-born batter had made a dramatic re-entry into the IPL mid-way through the 2022 season as a replacement player for Luvnith Sisodia in RCB after having previously played four games in 2021 for the franchise but was not retained later that year.
In eight games in 2022, Patidar aggregated 333 runs including an unbeaten 112 off 54 balls in the IPL Eliminator win against Lucknow Super Giants. Patidar later missed the 2023 season due to an Achilles Heel injury but was retained by the franchise for another season. In 2024, Patidar was at his destructive best for RCB, smashing 33 sixes while amassing 395 runs in 15 matches.
reference_summary:
Virat Kohli has backed newly-appointed RCB captain Rajat Patidar to lead the team for many years, expressing confidence in his abilities. Speaking at RCB’s Unbox event, Kohli, who led the franchise for over a decade before stepping down in 2021, praised Patidar’s potential and expressed excitement for the upcoming IPL season.

Patidar, who replaced Faf du Plessis as captain, called it an honor to lead RCB, a team he has admired since childhood. The Indore-born batter made a significant impact in IPL 2022, scoring 333 runs in eight games, including a stunning 112* in the Eliminator. Despite missing the 2023 season due to injury, he was retained by RCB and delivered a strong performance in 2024, hitting 33 sixes and amassing 395 runs in 15 matches.

With a talented squad and Kohli’s endorsement, Patidar looks set to lead RCB into a promising new era.

[DOC 1] Panaji: After over nine years, the CBI had managed to identify and arrest a person as a suspect in the Mormugao minor girl rape case, but his fingerprints did not match the ones picked from the crime scene. Later, he was granted bail by a local court.
On January 14, 2013, a seven-year-old girl was raped in her school toilet in Mormugao taluka.
After the suspect, based on a sketch, was not traceable, a CBI team went to West Bengal and arrested him.The suspect was a native of Murshidabad, West Bengal, and was living in Goa.
Sources said that the arrested suspect’s fingerprints did not match that of the accused.
Earlier, Goa police and the CBI released three different sketches of the accused, but could not trace him.
After no breakthrough, the CBI had approached the judicial magistrate first class (JFMC), Vasco, in 2017 seeking permission to close the case. But the survivor’s parents objected to the closure and the CBI had to restart the investigations.
The CBI had carried out DNA tests on over 14 suspects and put eight suspects through the lie detection test.
It also did fingerprint matching of nine suspects, but did not get favourable results, and had filed the closure report.
It was transferred to Goa police’s crime branch on the same day.
In May 2013, an NGO demanded that the case be handed over to the CBI, as the local crime branch had failed to make any detection.
Agreeing to the demand, the state government accorded consent and after the Union home ministry issued a notification transferring the case, the CBI took over the case in September 2013.
In its closure report, the CBI had said that the culprit was not traceable despite all efforts.
The CBI had conducted polygraph tests on two persons suspected to have known the accused in the rape case.
The CBI officials especially flew down from Delhi and conducted the lie detection test on these two persons at the CBI’s Bambolim office.
reference_summary: In Panaji, the CBI arrested a suspect in the Mormugao minor girl rape case after nine years, but his fingerprints didn't match those from the crime scene. He was later granted bail. The case dates back to January 14, 2013, when a seven-year-old girl was raped in her school toilet. Despite various efforts including DNA tests, lie detection tests, and multiple suspects investigated, the case remains unsolved.

[DOC 1] Bharatiya Janata Party’s controversial MLA Surendra Singh, on Wednesday termed Congress president Rahul Gandhi as  ‘Ravana’ and his sister and Congress general secretary for UP East, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, as ‘Surpanakha’.

The BJP MLA said that the Congress was a ‘sinking ship’ and it managed to defeat the BJP in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh in the recent assembly polls because of resentment in a section of society over Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes Act.

He claimed that the Congress had no political standing anymore and it would not win anywhere else in the coming Lok Sabha elections.

Taking a swipe at the Congress, Singh said that as Ravana sent his sister Surpanakha to defeat Ram, Rahul too had pitched Priyanka to defeat Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

Earlier, the MLA had supported his party colleague and MLA Sadhana Singh, who created a political furore by using derogatory language against Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati at a public meeting at Chandauli.

Defending Sadhna Singh, Surendra Singh had said that Mayawati’s decision to join hands with Samajwadi Party after the infamous 1995 Lucknow Guest House incident proved that she had no self-respect.
reference_summary: Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) MLA Surendra Singh likened Congress President Rahul Gandhi to 'Ravana' and Priyanka Gandhi Vadra to 'Surpanakha,' denouncing Congress as a 'sinking ship.' He attributed Congress's recent state election wins to resentment over the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes Act. Singh dismissed Congress's electoral prospects, alleging it lacks political standing. He mocked Rahul for deploying Priyanka to defeat Prime Minister Narendra Modi, drawing parallels to the Ramayana. Earlier, Singh supported MLA Sadhana Singh's derogatory remarks against Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati, citing her alliance with Samajwadi Party after the 1995 Lucknow Guest House incident as proof of lacking self-respect.

[DOC 1] The National Population Register (NPR) form used at the trial stage in September 2019, seeking details of the “place of birth of father and mother”, is likely to be finalised as the authorities did not receive any adverse feedback from a sample set of respondents.

Around 30 lakh people responded to the “pretest” form that was used to collect data in 74 districts. It sought details on 21 parameters, especially the “ place of birth of father and mother , the last place of residence”, along with Aadhaar (optional), voter ID card, mobile phone and driving licence numbers.

The present NPR has a database of 119 crore residents.

“None of the respondents gave an adverse feedback. The final form is likely to remain the same,” the official said.

Another official said families will be informed in advance about the visit of an enumerator so that the documents of all individuals are readily available for verification.

“If there are 15 members in the family, the enumerators would give them a prior notice, so that documents of all are available when the field visit is undertaken. The enumerator will see the documents,” the official said.

The NPR training manual said the existing database would be updated by verifying the details of all respondents through house-to-house enumeration.

The NPR exercise conducted first in 2010 and subsequently updated in 2015 , collected details on the following 15 parameters only — name of person, relationship to head of household, father’s name, mother’s name, spouse’s name (if married), sex, date of birth, marital status, place of birth, nationality (as declared), present address of usual residence, duration of stay at present address, permanent residential address, occupation/activity and educational qualification.
Along with census
The fresh NPR data will be conducted from April- September 2020 along with the decennial Census exercise.

West Bengal and Kerala have issued orders that they will not allow NPR in their States. Chief Ministers of other Congress-ruled States have also declined to update NPR amid apprehensions that it will be followed by the National Register of Citizens (NRC). Though the government has denied that there was any link between NPR and the NRC, the Rules inserted in 2003 to the Citizenship Act, 1955 , clearly provides for the creation of NRC that will flow from data gathered in the NPR .

The Rules empower local officials to decide on a person’s citizenship status. The Assam-specific NRC, conducted under the supervision of Supreme Court, had excluded 19 lakh out of 3.29 crore residents. There are apprehensions that people will have to dig out old documents to prove their residency in India on the lines of the exercise conducted in Assam.

No documents need to be produced for NPR: Union Home Ministry
The Union Home Ministry on Wednesday clarified that no person needs to submit any documents during the house-to-house survey for updating the National Population Register and that information provided by individuals would be accepted and recorded.

Through a series of tweets, the Ministry sought to deny the thrust of a report in The Hindu headlined NPR trial form gets government nod for rollout that appeared on January 1.

The Ministry spokesperson’s official Twitter handle said: “The line taken by the story is incorrect, without taking into account the factual position for conducting NPR.” went on to say: “The story incorrectly quotes government officials that ‘respondents to NPR exercise will get time to provide papers’ and ‘families would need to dig out old documents and ensure that such documents are readily available for verification & enumerators would see those documents’.” It added: “The story ignores Government’s stated position that no individual will be required to submit any document to any authority or enumerator visiting his/her household for NPR survey. Information provided by the individual would be accepted and recorded accordingly.”
reference_summary: The National Population Register (NPR) is set to finalize its form after a trial stage in September 2019. Around 30 lakh people responded to the pretest form, which collected data on various parameters including the place of birth of parents and last place of residence. The finalized form is likely to remain unchanged as no adverse feedback was received. The NPR data collection will occur from April to September 2020 alongside the Census. However, West Bengal and Kerala have refused to implement NPR, citing concerns about its potential connection to the National Register of Citizens (NRC). The Union Home Ministry clarified that no documents need to be produced during the NPR survey, as information provided by individuals will be accepted and recorded.

input_text: [DOC 1] The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on Friday (May 5) searched seven locations in Mumbai including the premises of Jet Airways and its founder Naresh Goyal in Mumbai in connection with an alleged ₹538 crore bank loan fraud case. The CBI searches were spread across residences and offices of Mr. Goyal, his wife Anita Goyal, and former airline director Gaurang Ananda Shetty.  The agency has registered a new case of alleged bank fraud of ₹538 crore on a complaint from Canara Bank, they said.
reference_summary: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) conducted searches at seven locations in Mumbai, including the premises of Jet Airways and its founder Naresh Goyal, in connection with an alleged bank loan fraud case amounting to ₹538 crore. The searches covered the residences and offices of Naresh Goyal, his wife Anita Goyal, and former airline director Gaurang Ananda Shetty. The CBI initiated the action based on a complaint from Canara Bank, alleging a bank fraud of ₹538 crore.

[DOC 1] NEW DELHI: Having dethroned Bajaj Auto from its pole position in bike market, Hero Honda Motors Ltd has now set its sights on scooter market, which is witnessing a recovery.
Hero Honda plans to invest Rs 572 crore for expanding manufacturing capacities and also diversify into making scooters.
This move, industry observers say, will pit the company head-on once again with arch rival Bajaj.
Hero Honda has proposed this fresh investment in an application filed with government. The new product category â€” scooters â€” has been introduced in renewed licence and technical assistance (LTA) arrangement between the Munjal family-promoted Hero Group and Honda Motor.

According to sources, the company intends to produce mainly non-geared scooters, a growing segment in the country''s two-wheeler market today.

The scooter production, sources added, is expected to commence in its third plant that the company is planning to set up within a year. Hero Honda has already zeroed down on a few locations â€” including Uttaranchal and Himachal Pradesh â€” for setting up this plant.

The new plant, the source added, will have the flexibilty to produce both motorcycles and scooters. It has also proposed to add 1,500 jobs as part of this expansion and diversification.


Hero Honda forays into scooter-making at a time when its Japanese parent Honda is preparing to ride into the Indian motorcycle market. Honda â€” through its wholly-owned subsidiary Honda Motorcycles and Scooters â€” is set to launch its bike by Diwali.


"This does not mean any friction between the partners. The aim is to together control 50 per cent of the two-wheeler market in India by 2005," a company official said.
reference_summary: Hero Honda Motors Ltd, having surpassed Bajaj Auto in the bike market, now aims to enter the scooter market with a proposed investment of Rs 572 crore. The company plans to expand manufacturing capacities and diversify into scooter production, directly competing with Bajaj once again. The investment is part of the renewed license and technical assistance agreement between the Hero Group and Honda Motor. Hero Honda intends to focus on non-geared scooters, a growing segment in India's two-wheeler market. The production is expected to begin in a new plant, offering flexibility to manufacture both motorcycles and scooters. The company aims to add 1,500 jobs as part of this expansion and diversification.

[DOC 1] Shah Rukh Khan had a party at his house for the final, and half of B-Town was present. From the Roshans, to the Kapoors (and some other Khans) they all braved the traffic to make it to the actor’s bungalow in Bandra.

But they reached there only after jostling with the huge crowds outside SRK’s home.

Some like Arjun Rampal, who had gone to the stadium, joined in later. A few hours later, the crowd moved to Preity Zinta’s house, for her party. The revellers went back to their homes at 6 am.
reference_summary: Shah Rukh Khan hosted a star-studded party at his Bandra residence for the cricket final, attended by Bollywood celebrities including the Roshans, Kapoors, and other Khans. The guests, after battling through heavy traffic and crowds, continued the celebration at Preity Zinta's house later in the night. Arjun Rampal, who initially attended the stadium, joined the festivities later. The lively gathering continued until 6 am, showcasing the camaraderie and celebratory spirit among Bollywood personalities during the cricket event.

[DOC 1] Reiterating the UPA’s commitment to the welfare of ‘aam aadmi’, President Pratibha Patil today declared the government’s firm resolve to rein in prices of essential commodities and strengthen the country’s security apparatus to equip it to meet the challenge posed by terrorism.

Addressing a joint sitting of the two Houses of Parliament to kick-start the Budget session, she extended olive branch to Pakistan by stating that New Delhi was prepared to explore a meaningful relationship with the neighbouring country if it seriously addressed the threat of terrorism and took effective steps to prevent terrorist activities against India.

In her hour-long address, the President outlined the broad policies of the Manmohan Singh Government during its second term and what all it proposes to do in the coming months.

She maintained a stoic silence on the Telangana issue that has sharply divided members from Andhra Pradesh in Parliament.

Talking at length on security situation, Patil said the overall internal security, law and order and the communal situation remained largely under control during 2009. Infiltration of terrorists from across the line of control (LoC) in Jammu and Kashmir has gone up. Even then, the security situation has improved significantly in the state as well as in the North-East, but Left wing extremism continued to be a significant cause of concern.

As top leaders from both the ruling coalition as well as the Opposition parties heard the President with rapt attention, she said the government was committed to bringing forth legislation to ensure food security. Despite a significant increase in the procurement process of food grains, central issue prices for purposes of public distribution have been kept constant since 2002. The import regime for essential commodities has been liberalised. The government has decided to release 30 lakh tonnes of wheat and rice in the open market over the next two months, and release 5 lakh tonnes of wheat and 2 lakh tones of rice through the National Agricultural Cooperative Marketing Federation and the National Consumers’ Federation and their affiliated cooperatives to benefit consumers at the retail level. The government has also released an additional allocation of 36 lakh tones of wheat and rice for distribution to card holders over the months of January and February.

Touching a controversial issue that has sharply divided Parliament, Patil said the government was committed to ensuring early passage of the Women’s reservation Bill.
reference_summary: President Pratibha Patil reaffirmed the UPA government's focus on controlling inflation and strengthening national security. She expressed willingness for dialogue with Pakistan if it curbs terrorism. Addressing Parliament, she highlighted progress in internal security, food security measures, and support for the Women’s Reservation Bill, while avoiding the contentious Telangana issue.

[DOC 1] NEW DELHI: There is no proposal to ground Mirage-2000 fighter aircraft as there was no doubt regarding its reliability as an operational platform, Defence Minister Pranab Mukherjee said in Lok Sabha on Thursday.
"As of now there is no proposal to ground the aircraft. These aircraft are amongst the most modern fightern aircraft in the Indian Air Force inventory," he said during Question Hour.

Observing that the flight safety record of the fighter since its induction has been "excellent", Mukherjee said its operational capability had also stood the test of time in all crisis situation incluidng the Kargil conflict.
"There is no doubt regarding the reliability of this aircraft as an operational platform", he added.


Answering a question on the number of crashes of fighter planes since 2001, the Defence Minister said a total of 54 aircraft, including three Mirages, eight Jaguars and different types of MiGs, had crashed between 2001 and November nine this year.
The government had suffered a total loss of about Rs 1540 crore in these 54 air crashes, Mukherjee added.
reference_summary: Defence Minister Pranab Mukherjee assured Lok Sabha that there's no plan to ground Mirage-2000 fighter aircraft due to their reliability. He cited their excellent flight safety record and operational capability, including during the Kargil conflict. Since 2001, 54 aircraft, including 3 Mirages, crashed, resulting in a loss of approximately Rs 1540 crore.

[DOC 1] A day after Indian Foreign Minister S M Krishna announced that he would pay his maiden visit to Pakistan in July to hold talks with his counterpart Shah Mahmood Qureshi, the Bharatiya Janata Party has vehemently opposed resumption of any dialogue. In doing so, India’s principal opposition party has thrown a major dampener over the outcome of the talks.

BJP chief Nitin Gadkari, in an exclusive interview with The Tribune Editor-in-Chief Raj Chengappa here today, said: “India should not hold any talks with Pakistan — our party is against it. The talks will have no relevance as Pakistan has done nothing to end cross-border terrorism. By resuming talks with Pakistan, the UPA government would be repeating a big mistake.”

The BJP chief, who was in the city to address a series of rallies, charged the UPA government with using dilatory tactics and playing vote bank politics over the issue of carrying out the death sentence delivered to Kasab by the special court for his role in the Mumbai 26/11 attack. He said: “This government is always talking big but it has no courage to fight terrorism. The government has no guts to punish Afzal Guru though the Supreme Court has already given its judgment. It must now move fast on Kasab’s verdict and act on it.”

Gadkari was critical about the performance of the UPA government, which is set to complete a year of its second term on May 22. He said the government had failed to curb inflation and had totally failed “on internal and external security in terms of tackling terrorism and Naxalites. Overall, I would give it 0 out of 10 for its performance and 10 out of 10 on corruption.”

He was on the defensive though about his party’s flip-flop over developments in Jharkand and justified the BJP indulging in horse-trading to form a government there, saying it’s “in the wider interest of stability for Jharkand and to avoid President’s Rule.”

On the party’s failure of the cut motion in the Lok Sabha, the BJP chief accused the UPA government of misusing the CBI to blackmail the other opposition parties into compliance.
reference_summary: BJP chief Nitin Gadkari strongly opposed India resuming talks with Pakistan, citing continued cross-border terrorism. He criticized the UPA government’s inaction on executing Kasab and Afzal Guru, and rated its performance poorly on security and inflation. Gadkari defended BJP's actions in Jharkhand as necessary for political stability and avoiding President’s Rule.

[DOC 1] Prime Minister Narendra Modi Thursday said the INDIA bloc wants to make five prime ministers in five years and claimed that it will disintegrate after June 4.

Counting of votes for all the seven phases of the Lok Sabha elections will be undertaken on June 4.

Addressing an election rally in support of the BJP candidate, the PM said the INDIA bloc wants to replace the stable NDA government and make five prime ministers in five years.

"Many things will happen after June 4. The INDI alliance will disintegrate and they will look for a scapegoat after the defeat."

In an apparent attack on Congress leader Rahul Gandhi and Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav, he said, "The shehzade (princes) of Lucknow and Delhi will leave for abroad on summer vacations," said Modi.

Commenting that running a country is not a play for those born with a golden spoon, Modi said, "They have gone from Amethi and will go even from Rae Bareli
reference_summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi claimed on Thursday that the INDIA bloc aims to install five prime ministers in five years and will disintegrate after June 4, when votes for the Lok Sabha elections are counted. Addressing a rally, Modi criticized the bloc's leaders, suggesting they will flee abroad after the anticipated defeat. He described their leadership as inexperienced and criticized them for abandoning their constituencies. Modi's remarks underscore his belief that the INDIA alliance will fail and reflect his ongoing campaign efforts against the opposition.

to take the first jab of COVID vaccine here on Thursday.
The 79-year-old former player, accompanied by his wife Satya Misra, took the first dose at

against the dreaded pandemic.”
“I thought since the governments, both at the Centre and States, have been doing so much

“It was not at all painful and I appreciate the way the medical staff at the hospital were so
meticulous in everything, including registration and ensuring it was a pain-free process
for both of us lasting just about 45 minutes,” said Misra, who played in three consecutive
Wimbledon championships between 1964-66.
Misra, popularly known as SP in sporting circles, added that it was important to eradicate
the pandemic and for this, everyone has to chip in his or her own way.

Misra emphasized his role in contributing to the nation's fight against the pandemic, praising the efficiency and pain-free process administered by the hospital staff. He highlighted the importance of collective effort in eradicating COVID-19, underscoring the responsibility of every citizen in supporting government initiatives.

[DOC 1] NEW DELHI: After a week's break, the trial in the 2G spectrum allocation scam case, involving former Telecom Minister
A Raja, DMK MP Kanimozhi and corporate honchos as accused, will resume tomorrow in a Delhi court.
The day-to-day trial in the special court had to be adjourned for a week due to winter break and would continue from
tomorrow with Raja questioning his former aide Aseervatham Achary, a key witness in the case.
Achary, who is testifying as seventh prosecution witness, has so far stood by his earlier statements made to the CBI
indicting Raja and others.
During his cross-examination, Achary, a former Additional Private Secretary of Raja, had created a flutter in the court on
December 22 by saying that he was facing threat to his life.
He had told Special Judge O P Saini that a man present in the courtroom was threatening him. The person, identified as
Jai Prakash who was working as a peon with Reliance Power in Noida, was detained by the police but released later on
after a day-long interrogation.
Raja, however, had told the court that it was a "drama" by Achary and it was "planned" in "collusion" with the CBI to
"adversely impact" co-accused R K Chandolia's bail plea, which is slated for hearing in the Supreme Court this month.
reference_summary: The trial in the 2G spectrum allocation scam, involving A Raja, Kanimozhi, and corporate figures, resumes in Delhi after a week's break. Raja, former Telecom Minister, questions his ex-aide Aseervatham Achary, a key witness. Achary, maintaining his earlier statements, expressed fear for his life during cross-examination, alleging threat from a person later detained by police. Raja dismisses it as a "planned drama" to impact a co-accused's bail plea. The trial, adjourned for winter break, continues amid intrigue and accusations, shedding light on one of India's biggest corruption scandals.

[DOC 1] Nepal has an unenviable record of air tragedies on its mountains but course correction is missing

In an eerie reminder of a crash that occurred on May 14, 2012, a plane flying from Pokhara to Jomsom crashed near the Jomsom Airport, killing 15 people. Ten years later, in the same month and on the same route, another aircraft apparently hit a mountainside, crashed and snuffed out 22 lives. The 2012 flight was operated by Agni Air, Nepal’s domestic airliner, flying a Dornier Do-228 plane. This time, it was a turboprop Twin Otter 9N-AET aircraft belonging to Tara Air. The airline came into business in 2009 to help develop rural Nepal, and claiming to be the “newest and biggest” airline service provider in the Nepalese mountains. However, air tragedies are nothing new in Nepal’s hilly terrain. These are frequent and inquiry commissions are set up after each such accident but hardly any tangible steps are taken for course correction. For one, most of the aircraft in service are old planes, some of these being a second-hand buy. Another reason is the lack of modern navigational and technical facilities to aid the pilots and the Air Traffic Controller during inclement weather, which is a rather frequent and unpredictable phenomenon in any mountainous area.

The airlines, in their desire to make a quick buck, resort to underhand tactics like hiring semi-qualified staff to operate the almost-ramshackle planes. Nepal, home to eight of the world’s highest 14 mountains, including Everest, has an unenviable record of air accidents. In 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying on the same route crashed soon after take-off. In March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board. Earlier, in September 2012, a Sita Air flight crashed while making an emergency landing at Kathmandu’s Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 19 people. In the latest incident, the small plane with 22 people on board, including four Indians, flying on a popular tourist route went missing in the mountains of Nepal on Sunday. The aircraft, on a 15-minute flight from Pokhara to Jomsom, both popular destinations with foreign hikers who trek on mountain trails as well as Indian and Nepalese Hindu devotees who visit the revered Muktinath temple, lost contact with the ATC shortly after taking off. The crash took place at Thasang-2 in Mustang district at a height of 14,500 feet.
reference_summary: This article discusses the recent plane crash near Jomsom Airport in Nepal, highlighting the unfortunate recurrence of air tragedies in the region. The incident, involving a Tara Air turboprop Twin Otter aircraft, claimed the lives of 22 people on a popular tourist route from Pokhara to Jomsom. The article notes that Nepal has a history of frequent air accidents in its hilly terrain, and various inquiry commissions have been set up after such incidents. The author points out contributing factors to these accidents, including the use of old planes, some of which are second-hand purchases, and the lack of modern navigational and technical facilities, particularly crucial in unpredictable mountainous weather. The desire for quick profits leads airlines to employ semi-qualified staff to operate aging aircraft. The article reflects on Nepal's air safety challenges and the need for tangible measures to address these issues and prevent future accidents. The tragic history of air accidents in Nepal, including previous crashes on the same route, is outlined to underscore the urgency of addressing safety concerns in the aviation sector.

[DOC 1] New York: Oil prices were tanking. Emerging-market currencies were in a freefall. Venezuela was mired in a financial crisis and Russia had sunk into a debt default and devaluation.


The year was 1998. Emerging markets on Tuesday look a lot like they did back then. Yet there have been key changes that could help most of them escape full-blown crises. Here’s a look at the similarities and differences between now and then.

Similarities:

Falling oil prices

Crude has dropped 48% since June to about $55 a barrel, squeezing exporters from Venezuela to Russia and Nigeria. Credit default swaps show a 97% probability that Venezuela will default on its bonds within five years, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The Russian economy, which is under sanctions by the US and the European Union over the Ukraine conflict, will contract as much as 4.7% next year if oil remains at $60, the central bank said.


Currencies sink

A Bloomberg index tracking 20 of the most traded emerging- market currencies fell to the lowest since 2003 on 15 December. The ruble tumbled past 64 per dollar for the first time, Turkey’s lira fell to an all-time low while Indonesia’s rupiah retreated to levels last seen in 1998.

During the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, countries from Thailand to Malaysia capitulated on defending their currency pegs, leading the Thai baht to lose half its value in six months. South Koreans lined up in the streets to donate gold jewellery to help the government refill their depleting foreign reserves amid the currency slump.

Fed policy

The US Federal Reserve is laying the ground for its first interest rate increase since 2006, threatening to drain capital from developing nations. The World Bank estimated last year that private capital inflows to developing nations could drop 50% should long-term US bond yields rise one percentage point.


Countries with large current account deficits, including Turkey, South Africa and Brazil, are vulnerable, according to Credit Agricole CIB. So are nations such as Malaysia, where foreign investors account for 30% of local government debt. A series of Fed rate increases in the mid-1990s helped trigger the run on Asian currencies that would in turn lead to Russia’s default.

Differences:

Flexible exchange rates

Developing countries have allowed their exchange rates to fluctuate, moving away from the fixed exchange-rate regimes prevailing during the crisis in the late 1990s. While weaker currencies fuel inflation, they can also stimulate economic growth by making exports cheaper.

Foreign reserves

Developing countries’"foreign reserves dwarf the amount they had in the late 1990s, which will help them weather the volatility in financial markets. As a group, emerging markets hold $8.1 trillion, compared with $659 billion in 1999, according to data compiled by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).


Debt

Instead of borrowing in dollars, the governments now mostly raise financing in local currencies, allowing them to pay back the debt without having to draw down foreign reserves.

External debt amounted to 26% of developing nations’ gross domestic product last year, down from 40% in 1999, the IMF data show.

One caveat is that companies have replaced governments as a source of concern on debt issuance. Corporations in developing countries sold about $375 billion of international debt between 2009 and 2012, more than double the amount in the four years before the 2008 financial crisis, the Bank for International Settlements said in September.

Interest rates

While rates are rising in some developing nations, they remain a fraction of the levels seen in 1998. Russia raised its benchmark rate 6.5 percentage points to 17% effective 16 December at a late-night meeting. Some short-term rates soared over 100% back in 1998.


In Brazil, policy makers have raised benchmark rates to 11.75%. That’s still less than half the rate levels from 1998. Bloomberg
reference_summary: The current economic landscape in emerging markets bears similarities to the 1998 financial crisis, with falling oil prices, sinking currencies, and the potential for adverse effects from US Federal Reserve policy. However, there are key differences that may mitigate the impact. Unlike the late 1990s, developing countries now have flexible exchange rates, larger foreign reserves, and reduced external debt as a percentage of GDP. Governments also borrow in local currencies rather than dollars. While challenges persist, these differences suggest that emerging markets are better positioned to weather potential crises than they were in 1998.

reference_summary: Low levels of radioactive iodine, believed to have originated from Japan’s damaged Fukushima nuclear plant, have been detected in air samples in Glasgow, Scotland. [DOC 1] Take an immersive tour of AlUla - with cues from Bollywood star Janhvi Kapoor - An extraordinary destination, this magical place holds secrets to be discovered!
AlUla, one of Saudi Arabia's oldest cities, is home to a multitude of fascinating ancient monuments. Bollywood's promising youth icon - Janhvi Kapoor reveals her memorable AlUla moments. We all know how much Janhvi loves travelling and exploring new and exciting places. Her Instagram is proof of the same. This time around, she had the time of her life while vacationing in AlUla. Janhvi on her personal Instagram handle says, "AlUla is a place of extraordinary human and natural heritage. A journey through a living museum of preserved tombs, sandstone outcrops, historic dwellings, and monuments, both natural and human-made, that hold 200,000 years of largely unexplored human history."
Here are the absolute must-visit locations in AlUla, feels Janhvi Kapoor: Hegra: Explore Saudi Arabia's first UNESCO World Heritage site where you can find 111 remarkably well-preserved tombs.
This scenic place surely will capture your heart. As you walk through the site, you'll find tombs dedicated to healers,
military figures, local leaders and others. Once you're in Hegra, make sure to uncover the wells and stone-lined water channels that display the superb craftsmanship.Elephant Rock:
Enjoy the view of the most amazing n a t u r a l formation. This landmark is set amongst a spectacular desert terrain and towers up to 52 metres into the sky, it is AlUla's most recognisable geological wonder. Throughout millions of years, wind and water erosion sculpted the instantly distinguished form, giving it its unique trunk and body shape. Open throughout the late nights, seize a seat in the sandy seating area, and revel in the breathtaking starry drawings that adorn the dark skies above the magnificent rock formations.Rainbow Rock Or The Arch Rock:
The Arch (also known as Rainbow Rock) is one of the most notable rock formations in AlUla. It seems like a rainbow caught between two clouds. For travellers, this unusual natural attraction with a bridge-like design is indeed unique. Low light pollution across AlUla makes the Rainbow Rock a perfect location for camping and stargazing. This location is known for its semi-precious desert diamonds, which many visitors come here in search ofMaraya:
Maraya is a stunning mirrored building located in the desert canyon of the Ashar Valley. While the structure itself is a
work of art, Maraya is also a multipurpose venue and the centrepiece of AlUla's growing arts and entertainment scene.
You'll be able to see this state-of-the-art structure is covered in 9,740 mirrored panels reflecting AlUla's beauty, making it the largest mirrored building in the world, according to Guinness World Records.Enjoy Seasonal Activities In Alula AlUla's exciting calendar of seasonal events has been developed to blend effortlessly and authentically with the environment. Right from November 2020, Adventure Hub started offering thrill-seekers a range of soft and hard achievements activities. Here's what you can try: Rides of AlUla: Extreme adventure enthusiasts could try the Harrat zipline, bump and pump bike park and dune buggie rides right through the desert landscape. It is very refreshing.
Adventure in AlUla: Take your family along on a spectacular horse trail amidst nature. Choose from a selection of walking trails to suit different levels of fitness. Relax and rejuvenate: Spa experiences include treatments developed from the miracle Moringa plant, native to AlUla. This plant can be made into oils, creams, soaps with intensive healing properties.
Stargazing in Gharameel: Surrounded by Gharameel's magical rock formations, you can gaze at a blanket of stars while also enjoying a lavish spread of traditional grilled supper.
reference_summary: AlUla, Saudi Arabia's ancient city, enchants visitors with its rich heritage and natural wonders, as described by Bollywood star Janhvi Kapoor. Highlighted spots include Hegra, boasting 111 well-preserved tombs and intricate water channels. Elephant Rock stands out with its towering formation sculpted by wind and water erosion, offering stunning desert views and starlit nights. Rainbow Rock captivates with its bridge-like formation amid low light pollution, ideal for stargazing. Maraya, the world's largest mirrored building, dazzles in Ashar Valley, reflecting AlUla's beauty. Seasonal activities like ziplining and desert adventures add thrill, complemented by spa treatments and stargazing amidst Gharameel's magical rocks.

[DOC 1] GANDHINAGAR: BJP is witnessing dissidence and protests after it announced candidates’ list for the Gujarat assembly polls.

Several party workers reached Kamalam, the swanky headquarters of the ruling party in the outskirts of Gandhinagar, on Sunday and “warned BJP of consequences if their demands aren’t met”. Also, many workers took to the streets to protest either the dropping of the sitting MLAs or repeating the unpopular ones.

BJP workers admit that while post-ticket allocation resentment is not new to the party, the scale of protest unleashed this time around is unprecedented. “Absence of Modiji has emboldened the ambitious candidates,” said a mid-level Ahmedabad-based worker.

The supporters of heavyweight Rajput leader IK Jadeja flocked Kamalam on Sunday after he was denied a ticket from Wadhwan. BJP has fielded Dhanji Patel, a first-timer. While Dhanji belongs to the same Leuva sub-caste as Hardik, Jadeja maintains the people of Dhrangadhra and workers of Wadhwan wanted him as BJP candidate, but lost patience when an outsider was fielded by the party. Jadeja, however, reiterated that he was very much in BJP.


But Liladhar Vaghela — BJP MP from Patan — has threatened to resign if his son Dilip is not fielded from Deesa in North Gujarat. Another BJP MP from Panchmahal, Prabhatsinh Chauhan, has decided to file his nomination papers as an independent from Kalol after his request for a ticket for his wife was turned down.

Workers from Nikol in Ahmedabad too thronged Kamalam on Sunday protesting the repeat of Ahmedabad BJP city chief Jagdish Panchal from the constituency. Alleging arrogance and high handedness on the part of Panchal, the workers demanded that he be dropped.

Resentment was also felt in Naroda in Ahmedabad, where the supporters of sitting MLA Nirmala Wadhwani protested her dropping.
reference_summary: The announcement of candidates for Gujarat's assembly polls has sparked dissension within the BJP. Party workers protest at the Gandhinagar headquarters over dropped or unpopular choices. Notable leaders, like IK Jadeja, face dissent, while MPs Liladhar Vaghela and Prabhatsinh Chauhan express dissatisfaction. The BJP contends with internal discord ahead of elections.

[DOC 1] BOSTON, January 27 (PTI):  The heroic response by employees of Mumbai’s landmark Taj Hotel during the 26/11 terror attacks is now a case study at Harvard Business School that focuses on the staff’s selfless service for its customers and how they went beyond their call of duty to save lives. The multimedia case study ‘Terror at the Taj Bombay: Customer-Centric Leadership’ by HBS professor Rohit Deshpande documents “the bravery and resourcefulness shown by rank-and-file employees” during the attack.
The study mainly focuses on “why did the Taj employees stay at their posts (during the attacks), jeopardising their safety in order to save hotel guests” and how can that level of loyalty and dedication be replicated elsewhere. A dozen Taj employees died trying to save the lives of the hotel guests during the attacks. “Not even the senior managers could explain the behaviour of these employees,” Deshpande is quoted as saying in HBS Working Knowledge, a forum on the faculty’s research and ideas. Deshpande said even though the employees “knew all the back exits” in the hotel and could have easily fled the building, some stayed back to help the guests.
“The natural human instinct would be to flee. These are people who instinctively did the right thing. And in the process, some of them, unfortunately, gave their lives to save guests.” A documentary-style account of events, the case includes video interviews with hotel staff and footage of the attack. It shows how leadership displayed by people in the bottom rank to the top levels in the organisational hierarchy helped in saving lives. It also focuses on the hotel’s history, its approach to recruiting and training employees, the Indian culture’s “guest is God” philosophy and how the hotel would recover after the attacks. Another key concept of the study is that in India and the developing world, “there is a much more paternalistic equation between employer and employee that creates a kinship.”
Terming it as one of the “hardest cases” he has worked on, Mumbai-native Deshpande said it was hard to see people confront their trauma again. “We objectify it, keep emotion at a distance, but after 15 minutes of questions with a video camera in a darkened room, there are deeper, more personal reflections of what happened,” he says in the HBS Working Knowledge. Deshpande said Taj employees felt a sense of loyalty to the hotel as well as a sense of responsibility to the guests. He cites the example of a general manager who insisted on staying put and help direct a response to the attack even after learning that his wife and sons had died in a fire on the hotel’s top floor.
“Nothing in the employees’ training could have prepared them for such an unprecedented situation,” Deshpande said. Deshpande has taught the case in the School’s Owner/President Management Executive Education programme. It can also be taught as an example of managing the post-crisis recovery of a flagship corporate brand, he added.
reference_summary: The heroic response of Taj Hotel employees during the 26/11 terror attacks in Mumbai has become a case study at Harvard Business School. Titled 'Terror at the Taj Bombay: Customer-Centric Leadership,' the study by HBS professor Rohit Deshpande explores the bravery and selflessness exhibited by staff in saving guests' lives. It focuses on the loyalty and dedication of employees who stayed at their posts despite the danger. The case study also delves into the hotel's history, employee recruitment, training, and the recovery process after the attacks, highlighting the unique employer-employee relationship in India.

[DOC 1] Popular Bengali novelist Bimal Mitra passed away on this day. He also wrote in Hindi. His best-known work is Shaheb Bibi Golam, which was made into both Bengali and Hindi films.

Mitra was a railways employee. His experience of life in Chakradharpur Division, now in Jharkhand, made its way into his fiction. He resigned from the railways in 1950, in his late 30s, and became a full-time writer. He was a prolific writer. His novels were expansive sagas of individual lives caught up in a world of enormous social and political change.

Shaheb Bibi Golam, the Hindi version of which was acted in and produced by Guru Dutt, is a story set against a decadent feudal society and revolves around “Chhoto Bou” (played by Meena Kumari in the Hindi version), a woman married into a zamindar family who yearns for love, romance and the fullness of life, which elude her. Mitra’s other famous novels include Asami Hajir and Kori Diye Kinlam. His books were translated into many Indian languages.
reference_summary: Bimal Mitra, a popular Bengali novelist, passed away on this day. He was also known for his works in Hindi. One of his most famous novels is "Shaheb Bibi Golam," which was adapted into both Bengali and Hindi films. Mitra, who had a background as a railways employee, drew inspiration from his experiences in the Chakradharpur Division for his fiction. He resigned from the railways in 1950 to become a full-time writer. Known for his prolific writing, Mitra's novels delved into the complexities of individual lives amidst significant social and political changes.

[DOC 1] After the 26/11, the coastal security agencies have geared up to take stringent measures to ensure that another Kuber is not repeated. The decision on the same lies with the state government and the central government. One of the pertinent security measures which is being discussed suggests that 10 nautical miles across the International Maritime Border line should be made a No-fishing-Zone. In some of the countries like in the USA fishing is allowed only in certain coastal belts taking security into consideration. Security agencies also suggested that No-Fishing -Zone should also be introduced at harbour. According to them, this step will ensure zero chance to interface with bigger vessels.
 
 According to the information available with the Newsline, the number of fishing trawlers that have trespassed the International Maritime Border Line and entered the Pakistan waters increased to 800 trawlers in 2007, compared to 200 in 2004. Since 2005, as many as 2,495 Indian fishing trawlers have trespassed entered Pakistan waters. Among them, over 300 fishing trawlers are still with Pakistan and over 490 odd fishermen are in their custody. The IMB line is 85 miles away from Okha and 45 nautical miles away from Jhakau.
 
 The other important input passed on to the state by the coastal security agencies is that most of these trawlers were found to be fitted with GPS and high-end communication kits and were communicating with each other while sailing in Pakistan waters.
 
 Another pertinent measure that the security agencies suggested is cancellation of permits, if any fishing trawler crosses the IMB line to Pakistan waters. According the senior officials, Kuber had trespassed 70 nautical miles into Pakistan water. Kuber's GPS had recorded its location 10 nautical miles near Karachi coastline, they said. To prevent these kinds of incidents, only measure that should be taken is to deprive the sailors of diesel subsidy, if they are found to have trespassed into the neighbouring countries' waters.
reference_summary: After the 26/11 attacks, coastal security agencies have taken stringent measures to prevent another Kuber trespassing the International Maritime Border Line (IMB) into Pakistan's waters. The decision lies with the state and central governments. One proposed security measure is to create a No-Fishing-Zone 10 nautical miles across the IMB, similar to how fishing is allowed in certain coastal belts in the USA. The security agencies also suggest introducing a No-Fishing-Zone at the harbor to prevent bigger vessels from interacting. The number of Indian fishing trawlers entering Pakistan's waters has increased since 2005, with over 300 still with Pakistan and 490 in custody. Most trawlers are fitted with GPS and high-end communication kits, and security agencies suggest canceling permits if any crosses the IMB line to Pakistan waters.

input_text: [DOC 1] CHENNAI: A 43-year-old film producer who was related to director-actor M Sasikumar, committed suicide at his apartment complex in Arcot Road, Valasaravakkam on Tuesday morning allegedly following a threat from a Madurai-based film financier from whom he had borrowed money on interest.Police have booked the film financier Anbu Chezian on the charges of abetment of suicide. They identified the deceased as B Ashok Kumar, who is also a co-producer at Company Productions, the film production unit run by the actor.He left behind a suicide note mentioning the film financier Anbu Chezian's name, holding him responsible for his death.Police said on Tuesday morning, Kumar’s friends tried calling him but he failed to answer calls.One of his friends came home looking for him. As repeated calls failed to elicit response, he peeped through the window and found him hanging from the ceiling.The Valasaravakkam police recovered the suicide note in which he apologized to Sasikumar claiming he was responsible for the loss that the company had incurred for the past seven years and that he was unable to repay the loan.“He stated that the film financier issued life threats to his family despite paying exhorbitant interest for the last seven years,” said an investigating officer.He alleged that the financier has political clout and could escape easily.Kumar said he was unable to see the actor stressed over a mistake he made. He ended his note saying this letter could be easily tampered with. On Tuesday evening, Sasikumar along with other film directors lodged complaint against the financier. The Valasaravakkam police who registered a case under ipc Section 306 (Abetment of suicide), have launched a hunt for the financier. Anbu Chezian, 43, of South Masi Street was already arrested in Madurai, for extorting money from one of the producers in 2011.
reference_summary: A 43-year-old film producer, B Ashok Kumar, committed suicide at his apartment complex in Valasaravakkam, leaving behind a suicide note blaming Madurai-based film financier Anbu Chezian for his death. Kumar mentioned in the note that he was unable to repay the loan and was facing life threats from the financier despite paying high interest for seven years. The police have booked Anbu Chezian for abetment of suicide. Sasikumar, who is related to the deceased, along with other film directors, lodged a complaint against the financier. Anbu Chezian was previously arrested for extorting money from another producer in 2011.

[DOC 1] MUMBAI: India has rejected a drug patent application of a US multi-national pharma company, paving way for easy
access to an important life-saving medication for HIV patients across the globe.
The decision to reject the patent application on the important combination drug, Lopinavir/Ritonavir filed by Abbot
Laboratories was given by the Indian patent office here during the weekend and it is a major victory to millions of HIVpositive patients around the globe, according to NGOs working with affected patients.
The Indian patent office has put a halt to the multi-national Abbott Laboratories patenting and said it was not an
invention.
"India, the world's leading supplier of affordable medicines, can now supply this drug to patients across the globe who
are desperately waiting for treatment. This combination drug is considered to be the frontline of defense for HIV positive
patients who have failed to stay healthy with the first round of medicines available currently," Tahir M Amin, Director of
Initiative for Medicines, Access & Knowledge (I-MAK), one of those who initiated legal action against the US company
told PTI today in a communication from New York.
"This ground-breaking victory for patients sets an important precedent to stop pharmaceutical companies from gaming
the patent system, marking a new era of hope for millions of HIV people across the world," Amin said.
I-MAK was one of the opponents from US and others were Indian pharma companies like Cipla (Mumbai), Matrix
Laboratories (Secunderabad) and Okasa Pharmaceuticals (Mumbai).
reference_summary:
India's rejection of a patent application from Abbott Laboratories for the drug combination Lopinavir/Ritonavir has significant implications for global access to HIV treatment. The decision by the Indian patent office in Mumbai over the weekend has been hailed as a victory for millions of HIV-positive patients worldwide, particularly by NGOs involved in patient advocacy.

Abbott Laboratories' patent application was denied on the grounds that the drug combination did not constitute a new invention. This ruling clears the way for India, known as a major supplier of affordable medicines, to continue producing and supplying this critical medication to patients globally. Lopinavir/Ritonavir is considered essential for HIV-positive individuals who have not responded well to initial treatment options currently available.

Tahir M Amin, Director of Initiative for Medicines, Access & Knowledge (I-MAK), based in New York, emphasized the importance of this decision in preventing pharmaceutical companies from manipulating patent laws. He sees it as a landmark victory that will set a precedent for ensuring broader access to essential medications, offering renewed hope to millions affected by HIV.

Among the opponents to Abbott Laboratories' patent application were not only international organizations like I-MAK but also prominent Indian pharmaceutical companies such as Cipla, Matrix Laboratories, and Okasa Pharmaceuticals. Their collective efforts underscored the global significance of this decision in promoting affordable access to life-saving treatments.
